headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: My name is Rachel and will be conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone, to the RockTenn Second Quarter Fiscal 2015 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Ladies and gentlemen, this call is being recorded today,
componenttext: My name is Rachel and will be conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone, to the RockTenn Second Quarter Fiscal 2015 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Ladies and gentlemen, this call is being recorded today, April 30. [Operator Instructions] Your speakers for today's call are Mr.  Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer; and Mr. Ward Dickson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Voorhees, you may begin your conference.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Welcome to our call. This is the Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer, and I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Mike Kiepura, President of our
componenttext:
Thank you very much. Welcome to our call. This is the Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer, and I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Mike Kiepura, President of our Packaging Solutions business. During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discussed during the call. We described these risk is in our filings with the SEC, this includes our most recent 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2014, and 10-Q for the quarter ending December 31, 2014. We will also refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We provided reconciliations of this non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation. The slide presentations available on our website. 
I'm going to start by discussing our operating results, and then Ward will discuss our balance sheet, pension and various financial measures. I'll complete our prepared remarks with comments on the status of the merger of MWV and the outlook, then Ward, Jim and Mike and I will be available for your questions.
The RockTenn continued to deliver solid operating results in the March quarter. Adjusted earnings of editing $0.85 per share, were 35% higher than last year's adjusted earnings of $0.63 per share. This improvement was driven by strong results in our corrugated packaging segments, where segment income increased 28% over last year. This increase was a result of strong external demand in corrugated and solid commercial execution and operational improvement in our mills and box plan system. Additionally, we benefited from lower commodity cost. We were negatively affected by the combination of a substantial electrical failure at the Panama City mill and severe weather in February. These negative factors reduced earnings by $0.09 per share. We've seen our box shipments trend positively over the prior year shipments on a per day basis since the second half of September 2014. This trend continued during the December and March quarters for both RockTenn and overall industry. RockTenn's March quarter box shipments increased 5.4% on an equivalent per day basis and actual shipments increased 3.7%, both of these are as compared to the prior year. There was 1 less shipping day in the quarter of this year versus last year, and both numbers significantly exceeded the comparable industry numbers. We also saw very good end market demand in our folding carton business, where volumes up 1.1% compared to the prior-year quarter. Performance in our merchandising display business is not meeting our expectations. Segment income for the quarter was $12 million less than last quarter. I will speak to our display segment in more detail later in these prepared remarks. 
Our adjusted EPS of $0.85 is higher than the updated guidance range we provided at the end of March, while are performance exceeded these expectations, I'd prefer that we not see this amount of difference between our actual and estimated results, particularly this late in the quarter. We are right away update our forecast each month and in this circumstance, we faced a series of negative events during February in the 1st of March. This negative events included weather impacts of natural gas at 4 of our large mills, where service was unexpectedly curtailed, the electrical issue at Panama City and decline in demand for promotional displays. The cumulative impact of these events caused us to reduce our expectations, and with those facts, I felt compelled to update to our guidance. While we were reducing our expectations, we benefited from a number of positive factors during the last week of March, including strong demand and operational performance in excess of our expectations across all of our businesses, particularly in our mills. The roughly $0.10 difference between our reported results in the top end of the revised guidance range, to about 1/3 better mill and plant performance, 1/3 sales and 1/3 forecast conservatism.
Net sales of $2.5 billion, were 3% higher than last year's March quarter. The mill acquisition, which was completed in May of last year, the strong plant performance contributed to the revenue increase. RockTenn's credit agreement EBITDA of $1.6 billion for the last 12 months was $66 million or 4% higher than last year's quarter. We generated strong free cash flow of a $1.11 per share. We will absolutely maintain our focus on the strong free cash flow generation after the merger is complete. We ended the March quarter with an leverage of 1.74x, and our balance sheet is in great shape as we get closer to completing our merger with MWV.
Demand for corrugated packaging continued to be solid in this quarter with higher industry production of domestic and export containerboard in this quarter as compared to last year's March quarter. Industry box shipments in the March quarter were also higher than last year's March quarter by 3.4% on a per day basis as reported by the Fiber Box Association. The improved domestic and export containerboard volumes and box shipments resulted in healthy industry containerboard mill operating rates of 95.5% for the quarter. 
Demand for RockTenn's corrugated products was strong with export and domestic containerboard production improving more than the industry in the March quarter as compared to the prior year quarter. Export demand improved significantly, as our exports shipments of 206,000 tons in the quarter were up 19,000 tons or 7% from the prior year quarter, largely as a result of 3 factors. First, we added new customers. Second, we experienced improved demand in Latin America. And third, we added additional mill export volumes from our mill. Sequentially export containerboard volumes increased by 10,000 tons or about 4%. As compared to the December quarter of this fiscal year, export containerboard pricing was slightly lower by about $5 per ton as a result of changes in mix in the strengthening dollar. Our regional export mix was similar to last quarter, approximately 60% of our export shipments Latin America, 20% to the Middle East and 10% each to Europe and Asia. RockTenn's box shipments also surpassed the industry's year-over-year improvement, starting in mid-September 2014, we began to see our box shipments trend positively over the prior year shipments on a per day basis. The increased box shipments were due to healthy industry box demand as well as the progress that we've been making in our product quality, service and improving the customer experience. Box demand continued to strengthen in the March quarter. Our growth exceeded industry box demand with our box shipments improving by 5.4% on a per day basis compared to last year's March quarter. There was no benefit from the mill acquisition on these strong box numbers as the Tacoma mill operated no box plants. 
RockTenn's corrugated segment mill operating rate for the quarter was 92.6%. If you exclude the 80,000 tons of maintenance downtime we took during the quarter, our operating rate was 96.5%. Our April box volumes are also very strong month-to-date as they are up 4% on a per day basis as compared to last year. Both April's have the same number of shipping days.
Containerboard and box trends are reflected in our financial results for the quarter. Corrugated Packaging segment sales are $1.73 billion, increased from $1.65 billion in the prior year March quarter, an increase of 5%. Corrugated Packaging segment EBITDA margin for the March quarter was 17.3%, this is up 210 basis points from the prior year quarter. Our focus on operational improvements continues to drive positive results. Corrugated productivity improved by 1% over the March quarter of 2014. The benefits of the  installation have driven flexo folder gluer performance to record levels. For the quarter flexo folder gluer performance increased 19% as compared to the prior-year quarter, and it was up 6% sequentially. productivity also set a record with 5% improvement over the March quarter of 2014. Additionally, our container plant labor efficiency as measured by square foot produced per labor hour increased by 3% over the last year. 
During the March quarter, we continued to execute our long-term EVOL flexo folder gluer strategy in our box plants. We added 1 machine at our New Jersey plant. Through the end of March, we have installed 12 of total 30 EVOLs that we plan to install in fiscal year '17. In April, we installed an EVOL in ou r Montgomery, Alabama plant, and we will install another one later in the quarter in our Lancaster, Pennsylvania plant. These investments are greatly enhancing the capabilities and productivity of our box plant system. Our corrugated packaging team delivered excellent performance this quarter. I'm very pleased with our results that reflect both improving industry demand and the progress we're making on commercial and operational excellence initiatives.
During the March quarter, the CRB market strength in the SBS market remained in balance. CRB industry backlogs as of the week ending April 15, stood at 144,000 tons, 23% higher than last year's backlogs. RockTenn's CRB backlogs are about 3 weeks. SBS industry operating rates were at 95% within industry backlogs of approximately 4.5 weeks. RockTenn's most recent SBS backlogs are at about 8 weeks. RockTenn's SBS and pulp volumes were lower than the prior-year quarter as a result of the March major maintenance outage at  This was 1-month earlier than last year. Minor and major outages alternate every year. Industry folding carton volumes were down in the March quarter by 2.8% compared to the prior year quarter. As mentioned earlier, our folding carton volumes were up 1.1% for the same period driving our growth compared to the end industry. The RockTenn team performed extraordinarily well with net sales of $320 million, and this represents a record March quarter for the division. 
The promotional displays business has been impacted by the changing purchasing patterns of large retailers and consumer packaged goods companies looking to reduce their overall cost structure. Some large retailers are reducing the number of promotional displays in order to cut cost. Consumer packaged goods companies are actively evaluating their supply chain to reduce cost and in some cases that investing to reconfigure their distribution system. These changes had a direct impact on our results in the quarter. Merchandising display segment sales were flat as compared to the prior year quarter. The 2 acquisitions we made last year contributed $17 million in sales over the prior year quarter, and our sales of permanent displays increased by $3 million. Our sales of temporary display declined by $21 million from the prior year quarter.  
We have bad significant amounts of new contracted business, which have required investments in people and infrastructure, both to support the new business as well as future growth opportunities. Due to the changing market conditions and our previous investments to support the growth, we expect profitability in this segment to be about $25 million in fiscal year '15. In light of the change in customer demand or adjusting cost structure, and expect improved results in fiscal year '16. Merchandising display add significant value to our enterprise. Displays innovation and relationships helped both our container and folding carton businesses with new business opportunities. Displays purchases from our corrugated packaging and consumer packaging businesses also benefit RockTenn overall.
Lower recycle prices, soft demand in China and the West Coast labor disputes drive the negative year-over-year results in our recycling business. We believe the resolution for West Coast labor dispute and potential for stronger chance demand later in the year, will translate into stronger results. Our recycling business provide secure cost-effective access to recycled fiber. This provides a competitive advantage for our mill system and also provides market intelligence for our overall business. The recycling team does this very well. I'll turn it over to Ward, who will now discuss various financial aspects of our business. Ward?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. This quarter's selling price and mix were unfavorable to the March quarter of last year. This decline is primarily driven by the corrugated segment.  2/3 of this decline is related to the adverse impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar o
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. This quarter's selling price and mix were unfavorable to the March quarter of last year. This decline is primarily driven by the corrugated segment.  2/3 of this decline is related to the adverse impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar on export containerboard pricing and box shipments into Canada and Mexico. The remainder of the decline is largely due to customer mix changes in corrugated box. Domestic box pricing was stable during the quarter. Export containerboard pricing declined by $35 per ton year-over-year, with most of the decline occurring last summer and fall when the currency impacts were quite rapid. Export markets have stabilized and volumes continue to be strong and export prices only declined by $5 per ton on a sequential basis. We experienced the favorable cost environment this quarter and had net cost deflation of approximately $45 million as compared to last year. Energy prices, driven by a 40% reduction in natural gas, generated a $40 million a benefit. Declines in fiber cost, primarily recycled fiber, contributed approximately $30 million benefit. These benefits were partially offset by higher wage benefits and other cost inflation. We generated $22 million in cost-savings and productivity improvements, this quarter over the prior year and have good momentum as we enter into our merger with MWV. Nonrecurring items in the quarter included the impact of the Panama City electrical outage, to labor disruptions and scheduled maintenance outage, which occurred in the June quarter last year. We continue to generate strong free cash flow at a level of $159 million or $1.11 per share during the quarter. Over the last 12 months, we have generated free cash flow of $845 million, or $5.86 per share. At the end of March, our net debt was approximately $2.75 billion. Our LTM credit agreement EBITDA was $1.6 billion and our leverage ratio was 1.74x. At March 31, we had used all the $5 million of our U.S. federal and foreign net operating losses. We still have approximately $56 million of various state net operating losses and other state credits available for use in future years. We also have significant remaining U.S. federal biofuel, alternative minimum tax and other federal tax credit that can be used to offset a total of $188 million of U.S. cash taxes. We expect to use these during fiscal years 2015 and 2016. 
The June quarter should be the last quarter we make any substantial pension contributions into our U.S. plans. Immediately after the merger, we will merge the overfunded MWV plants with the RockTenn plants. 
In terms of our CapEx guidance. We expect that the RockTenn 2015 capital expenditures will continue to be in the range of $500 million to $550 million. Maintenance downtime in the March quarter of 93,000 tons was slightly higher than last year's downtime of 73,000 tons. The majority of this maintenance downtime is in our corrugated segment. The June quarter is our heaviest maintenance outage quarter as we have planned to take maintenance downtime of a 116,000 tons at several of our key mills. At the end of March, our containerboard system inventory was 40,000 tons higher than one year ago. We have increased our inventory levels to better support our customers. Our inventory will peak in May at 10,000 tons higher than March and then showed a decline from there by 50,000 tons by the end of September. Now I will turn it back over to Steve who will discuss our outlook.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. I'm pleased with our results this quarter and the strides we are making across our businesses and improving operating efficiency and offering customer-focused solutions. Our corrugated packaging business is performing very well. Box volumes
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. I'm pleased with our results this quarter and the strides we are making across our businesses and improving operating efficiency and offering customer-focused solutions. Our corrugated packaging business is performing very well. Box volumes are growing and box pricing continues to be stable. Domestic containerboard market conditions are solid and strengthening seasonally. Export market volumes continue to be strong and pricing is reasonable considering the currency situation. Our mills and box plants are operating well. Folding carton demand is also solid and we're strengthening in SBS and CRB markets and backlogs. 
Merger integration activity is going very well. We are on track to complete the merger in June. Our innovation teams are working to ensure we can hit the ground running on day 1, that we achieve and drive to exceed our synergy targets. As we work together, we continue to identify new opportunities. I plan to give a more detailed summary of our synergy and performance improvement opportunities as well as our roadmap to achieve them on our July earnings call. 
Our new company will have a great business platform, strong cash flows and a solid balance sheet. Our capital allocation will center around a leverage ratio of 2.25x to 2.5x. On day 1, our leverage ratio should be at approximately 2x excluding the benefit of future synergies. Our leverage ratio is higher than both companies current levels, because we will be funding approximately $750 million at closing to repurchase the necessary RockTenn shares to reduce RockTenn's ownership interest of the new company to below 50%, and we will also use these funds for to pay the transaction cost. With the strength of our balance sheet and underlying cash flows, we will have a balanced capital allocation strategy that will allow us to pay an attractive dividend, continue to invest in our business, take advantage of a creative the business of facilities including acquisitions and return capital to our shareholders through share repurchases. We considered postmerger dividend strategy, while that's the decision for the new board, I have some thoughts I will share with you now. With that many compositions with shareholders over the last 3 months, as always do, we listen. Our dividend policy should be that has a large cap component with strong cash flows, we should pay an attractive dividend when compared to large cap indices. When setting the dividend, we'll take into account the impact of plant spin, chemicals on our financial statements and also on our total market capitalization. I remain confident in the opportunities in front of us. This combination is a terrific opportunity to leverage the best of each company to create significant value for our customers and shareholders. As we expect to close on the merger this quarter, it's difficult to provide on guidance with respect to the reported results for the new company, that reported results would be a blend of both companies results during the quarter. If you're looking for helping in modeling, I would lead you to RockTenn's adjusted EPS for the June quarter on a stand-alone basis being about 20% higher than $0.85 we earned in the March quarter. Now with that, Jim, Mike, Ward and I are ready to take your questions.

It's not so substantial that I would change the $300 million, and I think I would point out when we get to July, I want put in context both that $300 million, but also in context the other productivity improvements that we have, so that U.S. analyst can track the overall performance as a company, and that's the intent. I'm just -- the mechanics of doing that math will be premature to provide that levels, at this point.

componenttextpreview: I think we are pretty pleased with where our inventories are. We are constantly focused, primarily I'm trying to satisfy our customers requirements with products on time and doing so in a way that delivers them with low-cost freight and the best logistics
componenttext: I think we are pretty pleased with where our inventories are. We are constantly focused, primarily I'm trying to satisfy our customers requirements with products on time and doing so in a way that delivers them with low-cost freight and the best logistics that we can. And what we've learned is, our system functions better with a somewhat higher inventory levels than shipments where we began 7 years ago, and as we look forward to the very heavy shutdown period that we have coming up our season maintenance requirements that are large mills, we need this inventory to carry us over, and I think we're really just right on track.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you think about the merger as it closes, that the thing is really fascinating that folks is, we now finally have pretty much all the paperboard substrates under one roof. And as we've seen in the corrugated world in the last, actually 30 years, but rea
componenttext: As you think about the merger as it closes, that the thing is really fascinating that folks is, we now finally have pretty much all the paperboard substrates under one roof. And as we've seen in the corrugated world in the last, actually 30 years, but really intensively in the last several is the vertical integration with the box system. And my perception is, when you look at paperboard, there is a lot less vertical integration. That most of the folding carton work is done by smaller private companies. Do you think that there is an opportunity for you to increase or is it a desire to integrate further down into converting over time, now that you have sort of the ability to self supply all these different substrates?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think its premature to come to that conclusion. I was with about 30 of our sales managers and last night and I think they're going to market. I met customers and I think our customers and salespeople are very enthusiastic about the prospect to going to
componenttext: I think its premature to come to that conclusion. I was with about 30 of our sales managers and last night and I think they're going to market. I met customers and I think our customers and salespeople are very enthusiastic about the prospect to going to market with that, and I think we are -- we sell a lot of paper to converters and we value those relationships. We also sell converted product to our customers, and we value those relationship. So I think it's hard to say that we would look at one or the others having a -- at this point a better -- and just being a better opportunity for us.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just, last question, if you could talk a little bit about the potential as you see the strong in the for the box business to should I say tension between continuing with the export strategy versus pulling tons out of the export market back
componenttext: Okay. And then just, last question, if you could talk a little bit about the potential as you see the strong in the for the box business to should I say tension between continuing with the export strategy versus pulling tons out of the export market back into the U.S. It would seem like given the differential and pricing, you're certainly, in the near-term, better off pulling board back in. On the other hand, you have to manage customer relationships overseas as well, and how do you think about that?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Jim Porter. I think we've shared previously, that we look at our business through really the 3 channels that we operate in. One, is our internal converted product channels, where we serve all of our domestic end use customers. Secondly, our domest
componenttext: This is Jim Porter. I think we've shared previously, that we look at our business through really the 3 channels that we operate in. One, is our internal converted product channels, where we serve all of our domestic end use customers. Secondly, our domestic independent customers. And thirdly, our international customers. And we really a very deep and rich relationship across the world with these customers, and so we value them all extremely much. However, we do look at the integrated profitability at each of those particular channels, and when we are making decisions about where we optimize our mix of business, we would shift volumes between those channels where the opportunities create the most cash flow. So that's how we think about it and we operate daily on that basis.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Mr. Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Mr. Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim just one more for you on containerboard. You mentioned your domestic prices were stable sequentially, despite the fact medium prices came down in February. Can you talk about whether you saw orders for the same impacts from that medium price reduction
componenttext: Jim just one more for you on containerboard. You mentioned your domestic prices were stable sequentially, despite the fact medium prices came down in February. Can you talk about whether you saw orders for the same impacts from that medium price reduction and given your view that conditions are fairly healthy, why medium prices came down in February?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'm generally pretty bullish frankly about all of our markets, and I think we're going into a period of seasonal strengthening. The medium things, I'm really not clear why published down. We didn't see a market shift. It did, and clearly in those
componenttext: Okay. So I'm generally pretty bullish frankly about all of our markets, and I think we're going into a period of seasonal strengthening. The medium things, I'm really not clear why published down. We didn't see a market shift. It did, and clearly in those situations where we have relationships that are tied to the index that it moves, but it's not going to impact our earnings significantly, and we clearly, do not see degradation in those markets, on the contrary, we see demand strengthening in the markets front. As you look internationally, demand is also quite solid, and for the last number of months, we've seen really pretty flat pricing environments across those markets. There certainly has been a currency-related bias, and so on a year-over-year basis, as we look at the weather has fallen that any softening in our export prices has been nowhere near that magnitude. So it's really attribute to the strength of our markets, and I feel pretty good about things.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one more on the box shipments for you and for your industry. Obviously, they were pretty healthy in the first quarter for you. Are you surprised by the extent to which shipments have held up, obviously the U.S -- the GDP number came in yesterday was
componenttext: Just one more on the box shipments for you and for your industry. Obviously, they were pretty healthy in the first quarter for you. Are you surprised by the extent to which shipments have held up, obviously the U.S -- the GDP number came in yesterday was not very good, the economy is just not looking all that hot yet, you're seeing pretty healthy demand. Are you all surprised by the rate of growth that you're experiencing that the industry is experiencing, given that you would think boxes would be a pretty good barometer what's happening more broadly?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, just the GDP number came out is disappointing. I think if you go behind the scenes on that, it's a drilling activity is down, oil and gas industry is down, I think the Long Beach situation had an impact. We're really affected by those directly. I
componenttext: I think, just the GDP number came out is disappointing. I think if you go behind the scenes on that, it's a drilling activity is down, oil and gas industry is down, I think the Long Beach situation had an impact. We're really affected by those directly. In fact, we're probably helped with that, because the reduced our prices, like we've seen as put more money in pocket to be able to in order to spend so we're making nondurable goods and box demand is going up higher within the economy, what we've experienced over the past call it 6 months, that's not surprising to me. The spread, I'm not a good enough judge to know what other spread is greater or one, I would've expected because I really would not have had an expectation for that.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I realized a lot of in parts in is display, I'd like to get a sense of what opportunities do have to improve profitability in this segment? Do you think you can get back to that in a call it maybe a $50 million quarterly run rate in 2016 or is that a 2017
componenttext: I realized a lot of in parts in is display, I'd like to get a sense of what opportunities do have to improve profitability in this segment? Do you think you can get back to that in a call it maybe a $50 million quarterly run rate in 2016 or is that a 2017 event, and how might -- can you comment on the mix of new business and how that will compare to your existing business?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't want to set an expectation what we would do in fiscal year '16. I think I'd commented we do have a bunch of moving parts. I'm feeling confident that we're going to get the business aligned to where it can be -- it can continue to be very profitabl
componenttext: I don't want to set an expectation what we would do in fiscal year '16. I think I'd commented we do have a bunch of moving parts. I'm feeling confident that we're going to get the business aligned to where it can be -- it can continue to be very profitable and important part of our business. We are on the front end of the changes, and I'd say the retail environment and the way the CPGs are to it. And so we're just right now  we're bearing the brunt of that. I think long-term, it's going to be very helpful, because we're going to be in position to understand what's happening in the retail market and for our consumer packaged goods companies. So we I think we're going to be able to have a very strong business, it's going to fit in very well with packaging solutions business of the merged company.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And my second question on the recycling business, you mentioned expectation for maybe stronger Chinese demand later in the year. I know we have seen the potential in trade reports but are you seeing that gives encouragement on this from your vantage point
componenttext: And my second question on the recycling business, you mentioned expectation for maybe stronger Chinese demand later in the year. I know we have seen the potential in trade reports but are you seeing that gives encouragement on this from your vantage point?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Deb, it's Jim Porter. China, well, I don't know, a short answer. We all know a bit about China, and it's been through a softening period. They still make a lot of paper over there. I think the port phenomenon really has dramatically shifted where that fib
componenttext: Deb, it's Jim Porter. China, well, I don't know, a short answer. We all know a bit about China, and it's been through a softening period. They still make a lot of paper over there. I think the port phenomenon really has dramatically shifted where that fiber had come from to supply their needs. And while they have been down over the last couple of years compared to where they were a few years prior to that, really have no line of sight as to what there true demand structure is going to do. But we do believe that, with the port situation easing, that a more normalized flow from North America to China will resume, which we would believe would create an upward bias to pricing. But going beyond that really would be a long shot call.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question will be coming from the line of Mr. George of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question will be coming from the line of Mr. George of Bank of America.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: When we look at the investments that you're making in the corrugated network, and certainly we are seeing improvement in earnings for RockTenn and that's a good thing, how do you balance the need to go with EVOL and more productive die cutters with that -
componenttext: When we look at the investments that you're making in the corrugated network, and certainly we are seeing improvement in earnings for RockTenn and that's a good thing, how do you balance the need to go with EVOL and more productive die cutters with that -- teh risk that you ultimately over-capitalized and you're creating more capacity than you would like in the converting business. Recognizing that converting is different than mills, you don't run to an operating rate per se, but tell us how you manage that risk, if you see it as a risk at all? And then the other portion I had, just on fixed cost, doing some very quick calculations, it seems like your fixed cost inflation is currently running at around a $100 million or so based on the fiscal 2Q result that's not different than what you have seen in the past. What can you do with anything to maintain that level, perhaps drop it or should we assume a 2% or 3% rate of inflation on fixed cost going forward?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think just with respect to box plant system, I think our company has a philosophy of matching our what we produced with market demand, and that's what we've done in container. Just in circumstances where we put in EVOLs, we have typically taken out 2 to
componenttext: I think just with respect to box plant system, I think our company has a philosophy of matching our what we produced with market demand, and that's what we've done in container. Just in circumstances where we put in EVOLs, we have typically taken out 2 to 4 older pieces of the equipment, couple of circumstances to where we will keep that maybe one of those machines in the corner in the event the demand goes up, but the economics of the EVOLs in addition to providing just a more efficient piece of equipment, because economics are accompanied by cost reduction when we put So I think that's response to your first question. The second question, I need -- we either need to go off-line, because I'm not tracking the $100 million to you.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest component of our non-commodity inflation is wage inflation, and we have a -- and that's in a -- we experienced a 2% to 3% wage and benefit cost inflation every year. That can easily be $60 million to $75 million of year of inflation that
componenttext: Well, the biggest component of our non-commodity inflation is wage inflation, and we have a -- and that's in a -- we experienced a 2% to 3% wage and benefit cost inflation every year. That can easily be $60 million to $75 million of year of inflation that we have to fight. It is part of the culture inside of a RockTenn that we drive cost reduction targets across the entire organization, our Six Sigma function support productivity initiatives in our manufacturing facilities, but as well we take the same approach in our support organizations and our operating expense structure. So that's an ongoing tension that's in the financial model that we are driving cost reductions against every year.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we're just -- a quick follow on, the 2% to 3%, is a net of the Six Sigma or you think the Six Sigma and other efforts can be lower that rate of growth? for double dipping there?
componenttext: So we're just -- a quick follow on, the 2% to 3%, is a net of the Six Sigma or you think the Six Sigma and other efforts can be lower that rate of growth? for double dipping there?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what -- I was identifying was this the inflation itself. The Six Sigma contributes to our productivity bought in our operating expense leverage and then also in our labor productivity that occurs in our facilities -- manufacturing facilities.
componenttext: So what -- I was identifying was this the inflation itself. The Six Sigma contributes to our productivity bought in our operating expense leverage and then also in our labor productivity that occurs in our facilities -- manufacturing facilities.

componenttext: Just following up on Chip's question on sales synergies with the new portfolio. Steve you referenced some excitement in the sales organization, and is it possible to say whether the upside in sales synergies come more from having all 3 box grades under the same roof or do you think there is more opportunities from having the leading containerboard franchise and the leading boxboard franchise under the same roof?

componenttextpreview: I think it's the breadth of product offering that we have, which included what you just talked about, and I think the converting as well as the paper, I'm just being able to talk to customers about the broad product offering, I think just ends up creating
componenttext: I think it's the breadth of product offering that we have, which included what you just talked about, and I think the converting as well as the paper, I'm just being able to talk to customers about the broad product offering, I think just ends up creating opportunities. I think one of the things MWV is bringing to the company is a -- just a great commercial excellence capability, and I think that's something we also have at RockTenn. I think the combined companies are going to -- we're going to be able to go to market and I think talk to customers and provide services. But I can't fully describe what's going to happen, but we've got great people and we've got customer opportunities, and I think extraordinary things will end up happening.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, following up on that prior to the merger, you made some realignments in our paper business and the packaging business were organized, and there was kind of goal of gaining some sales synergies on that reorganization. Have y
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, following up on that prior to the merger, you made some realignments in our paper business and the packaging business were organized, and there was kind of goal of gaining some sales synergies on that reorganization. Have you kind of seen some of it fruits of that realignment already -- with what's go in cycle?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have, and I think just -- we did organize into packaging solutions and paper solutions. We have had I think very good success going to the -- many of our customers with the broad product line and the addition of MWV just makes that even better. I think
componenttext: We have, and I think just -- we did organize into packaging solutions and paper solutions. We have had I think very good success going to the -- many of our customers with the broad product line and the addition of MWV just makes that even better. I think we did put out an announcement on executive and we maintained the packaging, paper solutions framework, and I think we are very good momentum on how we go to market, and have a lot of paper spending a lot of time on that. And I think the enthusiasm I see across the organization is deserved, and I think bear us well as we go forward.

componenttext: It's hard to quantify that. I think what we've seen gone through, I think a couple of cycles to where we lagged the industry now, we've got a quarter to where we exceeded the industry. I think you have to go back to the fundamentals what the management team has been doing in container, which I think is doing the right things with the long-term. And its a complicated project, its a multi-year project, and I think we are beginning to see the fruits of that. And so the box business right now is stronger than it has been ever been. I think that's because they are doing the right things that you ned to do operate the profitable box business.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: And then just on the cost side, in your slide deck you show a diesel exposure of 63 million gallon, what is that actually mean. So I guess from the high to where we are diesel prices are down about a dollar. So is that mean that on that component you should see a $63 million annualized benefit to the P&L, can you just provide a little more color around what your diesel exposure number in the presentation means?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that does show our volume of consumption on an annual basis. Embedded in our inflation numbers are the benefit that we've got from the lower diesel fuel surcharges that we have. It's partially offset though by higher freight rates. So the math is not q
componenttext: So that does show our volume of consumption on an annual basis. Embedded in our inflation numbers are the benefit that we've got from the lower diesel fuel surcharges that we have. It's partially offset though by higher freight rates. So the math is not quite $15 million worth of benefit in the quarter, it was something that was less than approximately $10 million, but it is flowing through the P&L, and it is one of the components of our deflation, but it's been partially offset by higher freight rates.

componenttext: Just taking backing off on question earlier, assuming deal closes as planned, is it fair to assume that another transformative acquisition probably and likely for next year or 2? Our primary focus now is to merge the companies, keep the organization working and get the most out of the existing organizations. So that's the job we are focused on now.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. componenttextpreview: I think we're on a very positive trend. We're seeing the start of April, very much like we saw in March, and seasonally we're going into it period, where winter is over, people are outdoors, they are spending more money on the stuff that we package, and s
componenttext: I think we're on a very positive trend. We're seeing the start of April, very much like we saw in March, and seasonally we're going into it period, where winter is over, people are outdoors, they are spending more money on the stuff that we package, and so I think the outlook is good. So that's really the run rate we see both in the folding carton as well as the corrugated business.

componenttext: Sure, I think it is similar to the strategy that you outlined on the containers side in terms of really focusing on satisfying the customers with outstanding quality and service, and doing that in a cost-competitive way, so to the extent that we bring the along those measures, that we're going to be rewarded with the business and folding has been taking an approach for the last many years, and certainly container -- after the acquisition 4 years ago, similarly. headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things Steve, first can you talk a little bit about your expectations for Virgin and recycle fiber costs in the next quarter. So, it doesn't look like input costs are clearly causing a lot of margin troubles so far, I'm just curious where you think th
componenttext: Two things Steve, first can you talk a little bit about your expectations for Virgin and recycle fiber costs in the next quarter. So, it doesn't look like input costs are clearly causing a lot of margin troubles so far, I'm just curious where you think that's going? And second, from your comments, it sounds like recycle and waste is maybe more of a strategically important cost centers than a meaningful profit center. I'm going to guess that you guys going to stop reporting it, so maybe this is the last time we get to see  it. Is there more restructuring to coming in that business, or should we just sort of think that what's its done for the last couple of years and what its going to do?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm going to take the second question, and Mike can start on the fiber while Jim to talk about the Virgin recycle. I think you articulated the recycling as a strategic cost center. We have out as a segment, but I think your view about is an appropriate vi
componenttext: I'm going to take the second question, and Mike can start on the fiber while Jim to talk about the Virgin recycle. I think you articulated the recycling as a strategic cost center. We have out as a segment, but I think your view about is an appropriate view, so I would not expect that to be reported as a separate segment. We have done a lot of restructuring in the business over a period of time. We shut down I think in excess of 10 plants and so with over -- as Jim is telling me 29 plants, and that's an excess of 10. But I mean we've done a lot of restructuring, and the impact -- the accumulated impact of that has been with our eye on the strategic cost centers as compared to standalone business. Our new segments will that going forward. I think with respect to Virgin and recycle, our Virgin cost have been have been -- demand extremely well. I think we just have a terrific procurement and we were I think that's helped -- we're reaping the benefits of that and I think with respect to the direction of Virgin and recycle Jim?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Steve. I would build on the kind of drive recycling business, because we're in the making and its all about fiber. And so our recycle system is very important to us as we use just 5 million tons, so we need to be very good at buying fiber, and that'
componenttext: Okay, Steve. I would build on the kind of drive recycling business, because we're in the making and its all about fiber. And so our recycle system is very important to us as we use just 5 million tons, so we need to be very good at buying fiber, and that's what that business allows us to do. We have rightsized with the closing over half of the facilities, and the ones remaining are very strategic parts of our business from a supply chain standpoint to supply our mills. So I think we've got that business on a very important state at present and costs have come down. With recycle, would down year-over-year -- were down sequentially quarter. We are generally very pleased with how our systems is functioning. Our team is really improved the management of our inventories and put our supply chains in a much better so that we're not having to react to weather and various special call situation. So we have got a much more stable and efficient work process. Will it turn it up or down? We think we're in a really pretty stable position relative to would. Recycle fiber, we've continuing to have a period of declining fiber prices. There are some that we may have and with the port situation cleaning up, we would expectation Asian demand to increase and we're starting to see that dip in the international markets. And so I would say there is likely some upper trend line on the fiber, but we don't see that as being something that is an extraordinary spike. I hope that's responsive.

componenttext: Thank you, Mark for that question. We get that often. But we have got a, I think a every good system and we have some very good competitors. I think you've seen us do a lot of heavy lifting to put our portfolio of containerboard mills and corrugated packaging operations under a much better state of management. The relationship with the customer has been an even the commercial our cost management have all been improved dramatically, and I think we're seeing that gap close, and you can bet every single day, we are focused on doing more of that. So I think over time, you will see us get better. I can't speak to what our competitors is going to do, but I'm not sure they are not going to stand still, and where it all goes from pure margin standpoint compared to metric, I really won't predict, but we are clearly focused on generating free cash flow for our shareholders and satisfying our customers.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: My name is Ajel. I will be your conference operator for today. Conference will run for 1 hour and at the end, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the RockTenn Second Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnin
componenttext:
My name is Ajel. I will be your conference operator for today. Conference will run for 1 hour and at the end, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. 
At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the RockTenn Second Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, slides are being presented today as part of the conference call. These slides can be accessed at www.rocktenn.com under the Investors page. 
Ladies and gentlemen, this call is being recorded today, April 30. [Operator Instructions] Your speakers for today's call are Mr.  Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer; and Mr. Ward Dickson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Voorhees, you may begin your conference.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Welcome to our call. This the Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer, and I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Mike Kiepura, President of our Pac
componenttext:
Thank you very much. Welcome to our call. This the Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer, and I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Mike Kiepura, President of our Packaging Solutions business. 
During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We described these risks and uncertainties in our filings with SEC. These include our most recent 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2014, and 10-Q for the quarter ending December 31, 2014. We will also refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation. The slide presentation is available on our website. 
I'm going to start by discussing our operating results, and then Ward will discuss our balance sheet, pension and various financial measures. I will complete our prepared remarks with comments on the status of the merger of MWV and the outlook. Then Ward, Jim, Mike and I will be available for your questions.
The RockTenn team continued to deliver solid operating results in the March quarter. Adjusted earnings of $0.85 per share were 35% higher than last year's adjusted earnings of $0.63 per share. This improvement was driven by strong results in our Corrugated Packaging segment, where segment income increased 28% over last year. This increase was a result of strong external demand in corrugated and solid commercial execution and operational improvement in our mills and box plant system. Additionally, we benefited from lower commodity cost. We were negatively affected by the combination of a substantial electrical failure at our Panama City mill and severe weather in February. These negative factors reduced earnings by $0.09 per share. We've seen our box shipments trend positively over the prior year shipments on a per day basis since the second half of September 2014. This trend continued during the December and March quarters for both RockTenn and the overall industry. RockTenn's March quarter box shipments increased 5.4% on an equivalent per day basis and actual shipments increased 3.7%, both of these are as compared to the prior year. There was 1 less shipping day in the quarter this year versus last year, and both numbers significantly exceeded the comparable industry numbers. We also saw very good end market demand in our folding carton business, where volumes were up 1.1% compared to the prior-year quarter. Performance in our Merchandising Displays business is not meeting our expectations. Segment income for the quarter was $12 million less than last quarter. I will speak to our Displays segment in more detail later in these prepared remarks. 
Our adjusted EPS of $0.85 is higher than the updated guidance range we provided at the end of March. While I like the fact that our performance exceeded these expectations, I would prefer that we not see this amount of difference between our actual and estimated results, particularly this late in the quarter. We regularly update our forecast each month and, in this circumstance, we faced a series of negative events during February and the first half of March. These negative events included weather impacts to our natural gas service at 4 of our large mills, where service was unexpectedly curtailed; the electrical issue at Panama City; and a discernible decline in demand for promotional displays. The cumulative impact of these events caused us to reduce our expectations, and with those facts, I felt compelled to update our guidance. While we were reducing our expectations, we benefited from a number of positive factors during the last week of March, including strong demand and operational performance in excess of our expectations across all of our businesses, particularly in our mills. The roughly $0.10 difference between our reported results from the top end of the revised guidance range to about 1/3 better mill and plant performance, 1/3 stronger sales and 1/3 forecast conservatism.
Net sales of $2.5 billion, were 3% higher than last year's March quarter. The Tacoma Mill acquisition, which was completed in May of last year, and the strong box plant performance contributed to the revenue increase. RockTenn's Credit Agreement EBITDA of $1.6 billion for the last 12 months was $66 million or 4% higher than last year's quarter. We generated strong free cash flow of $1.11 per share. We will absolutely maintain our focus on strong free cash flow generation after the merger is complete. We ended the March quarter with leverage of 1.74x, and our balance sheet is in great shape as we get closer to completing our merger with MWV.
Demand for Corrugated Packaging continued to be solid this quarter, with higher industry production of domestic and export containerboard in this quarter as compared to last year's March quarter. Industry box shipments in the March quarter were also higher than last year's March quarter by 3.4% on a per day basis as reported by the Fiber Box Association. The improved domestic and export containerboard volumes and box shipments resulted in healthy industry containerboard mill operating rates of 95.5% for the quarter. 
Demand for RockTenn's corrugated products was strong, with export and domestic containerboard production improving more than the industry in the March quarter as compared to the prior year quarter. Export demand improved significantly, as our exports shipments of 286,000 tons in the quarter were up 19,000 tons or 7% from the prior year quarter, largely as a result of 3 factors. First, we added new customers. Second, we experienced improved demand in Latin America. And third, we added additional mill export volumes from our Tacoma Mill. Sequentially, export containerboard volumes increased by 10,000 tons or about 4%. As compared to the December quarter of this fiscal year, export containerboard pricing was slightly lower by about $5 per ton as a result of changes in mix and the strengthening dollar. Our regional export mix was similar to last quarter, with approximately 60% of our export shipments to Latin America, 20% to the Middle East and 10% each to Europe and Asia. RockTenn's box shipments also surpassed the industry's year-over-year improvement. Starting in mid-September 2014, we began to see our box shipments trend positively over the prior year shipments on a per day basis. The increased box shipments were due to healthy industry box demand as well as the progress that we've been making in our product quality, service and improving the customer experience. Box demand continued to strengthen in the March quarter. Our growth exceeded industry box demand, with our box shipments improving by 5.4% on a per day basis compared to last year's March quarter. There was no benefit from the Tacoma Mill acquisition on these strong box numbers, as the Tacoma Mill operated no box plants. 
RockTenn's Corrugated segment mill operating rate for the quarter was 92.6%. If we exclude the 80,000 tons of maintenance downtime we took during the quarter, our operating rate was 96.5%. Our April box volumes are also very strong month-to-date, as they are up over 4% on a per day basis as compared to last year. Both Aprils have the same number of shipping days.
Containerboard and box trends are reflected in our financial results for the quarter. Corrugated Packaging segment sales of $1.73 billion, increased from $1.65 billion in the prior year March quarter, an increase of 5%. Corrugated Packaging segment EBITDA margin for the March quarter was 17.3%, this is up 210 basis points from the prior year quarter. Our focus on operational improvements continues to drive positive results. Corrugated productivity improved by 1% over the March quarter of 2014. The benefits of the EVOL installations have driven flexo folder gluer performance to record levels. For the quarter, flexo folder gluer performance increased 19% as compared to the prior-year quarter and was up 6% sequentially. Die cutter productivity also set a record with 5% improvement over the March quarter of 2014. Additionally, our container plant labor efficiency, as measured by square feet produced per labor hour, increased by 3% over last year. 
During the March quarter, we continued to execute our long-term EVOL flexo folder gluer strategy in our box plants. We added 1 machine at our Dayton, New Jersey plant. Through the end of March, we have installed 12 of total 30 EVOLs that we plan to install in fiscal year '17. In April, we installed an EVOL in our Montgomery, Alabama plant, and we will install another one later in the quarter in our Lancaster, Pennsylvania plant. These investments are greatly enhancing the capabilities and productivity of our box plant system. 
Our Corrugated Packaging team delivered excellent performance this quarter. I'm very pleased with our results that reflect both improving industry demand and the progress we're making on our commercial and operational excellence initiatives.
During the March quarter, the CRB market strength gained strength and the SBS market remained in balance. CRB industry backlogs, as of the week ending April 15, stood at 144,000 tons, 23% higher than last year's backlogs. RockTenn's CRB backlogs are at about 3 weeks. SBS industry operating rates were at 95%, with industry backlogs of approximately 4.5 weeks. RockTenn's most recent SBS backlogs are at about 8 weeks. RockTenn's SBS and pulp volumes were lower than the prior-year quarter as a result of the March major maintenance outage at Demopolis. This was 1 month earlier than last year. Minor and major outages alternate every year. 
Industry folding carton volumes were down in the March quarter by 2.8% compared to the prior year quarter. As mentioned earlier, our folding carton volumes were up 1.1% for the same period, driving our growth compared to the end industry. The RockTenn team performed extraordinarily well, with net sales of $320 million, and this represents a record March quarter for the division. 
The promotional displays business has been impacted by the changing purchasing patterns of large retailers and consumer packaged goods companies looking to reduce their overall cost structure. Some large retailers are reducing the number of promotional displays in order to cut costs. Consumer packaged goods companies are actively evaluating their supply chains to reduce cost and, in some cases, they're investing to reconfigure their distribution systems. These changes had a direct impact on our results in the quarter. Merchandising Displays segment sales were flat as compared to the prior year quarter. The 2 acquisitions we made last year contributed $17 million in sales over the prior year quarter, and our sales of permanent displays increased by $3 million. Our sales of temporary displays declined by $21 million from the prior year quarter.  
We have had significant amounts of new contracted business, which have required investments in people and infrastructure, both to support the new business as well as future growth opportunities. Due to the changing market conditions and our previous investments to support the growth, we expect profitability in this segment to be about $25 million in fiscal year '15. In light of the changing customer demand, we're adjusting our cost structure and expect improved results in fiscal year '16. Merchandising Displays adds significant value to our enterprise. Displays innovation and relationships helped both our container and folding carton businesses with new business opportunities. Displays purchases from our Corrugated Packaging and Consumer Packaging businesses also benefit RockTenn overall.
Lower recycled fiber prices, soft demand in China and the West Coast port labor disputes drove the negative year-over-year results in our recycling business. We believe the resolution of the West Coast labor dispute and the potential for stronger Chinese demand later in the year will translate into stronger results. 
Our Recycling business provides secure, cost-effective access to recycled fiber. This provides a competitive advantage for our mill system and also provides market intelligence for our overall business. The Recycling team does this very well. 
I'll turn it over to Ward, who will now discuss various financial aspects of our business. Ward?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. This quarter's selling price and mix were unfavorable to the March quarter of last year. This decline is primarily driven by the Corrugated segment. 2/3 of this decline is related to the adverse impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar on
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. This quarter's selling price and mix were unfavorable to the March quarter of last year. This decline is primarily driven by the Corrugated segment. 2/3 of this decline is related to the adverse impact of the strengthening U.S. dollar on export containerboard pricing and box shipments into Canada and Mexico. The remainder of the decline is largely due to customer mix changes in corrugated box. Domestic box pricing was stable during the quarter. Export containerboard pricing declined by $35 per ton year-over-year, with most of that decline occurring last summer and fall when the currency impacts were quite rapid. Export markets have stabilized and volumes continued to be strong and export prices only declined by $5 per ton on a sequential basis. We experienced a favorable cost environment this quarter and had net cost deflation of approximately $45 million as compared to last year. Energy prices, driven by a 40% reduction in natural gas, generated a $40 million benefit. Declines in fiber cost, primarily recycled fiber, contributed approximately $30 million benefit. These benefits were partially offset by higher wage, benefits and other cost inflation. We generated $22 million in cost-savings and productivity improvements this quarter over the prior year and have good momentum as we enter into our merger with MWV. Nonrecurring items in the quarter included the impact of the Panama City electrical outage, the La Tuque labor disruption and the Demopolis scheduled maintenance outage which occurred in the June quarter last year. 
We continued to generate strong free cash flow at a level of $159 million or $1.11 per share during the quarter. Over the last 12 months, we have generated free cash flow of $845 million or $5.86 per share. At the end of March, our net debt was approximately $2.75 billion. Our LTM Credit Agreement EBITDA was $1.6 billion and our leverage ratio was 1.74x. 
At March 31, we had used all but $5 million of our U.S. federal and foreign net operating losses. We still have approximately $56 million of various state net operating losses and other state credits available for use in future years. We also have significant remaining U.S. federal cellulosic biofuel, alternative minimum tax and other federal tax credits that can be used to offset a total of $188 million of U.S. cash taxes. We expect to use these during fiscal years 2015 and 2016. 
The June quarter should be the last quarter we make any substantial pension contributions into our U.S. plans. Immediately after the merger, we will merge the overfunded MWV plans with the RockTenn plans. 
In terms of our CapEx guidance. We expect that the RockTenn 2015 capital expenditures will continue to be in the range of $500 million to $550 million. Maintenance downtime in the March quarter of 93,000 tons was slightly higher than last year's downtime of 73,000 tons. The majority of this maintenance downtime is in our Corrugated segment. The June quarter is our heaviest maintenance outage quarter, as we plan to take maintenance downtime of 116,000 tons at several of our key mills. At the end of March, our containerboard system inventory was 40,000 tons higher than 1 year ago. We have increased our inventory levels to better support our customers. Our inventory will peak in May at 10,000 tons higher than March and then should decline from there by 50,000 tons by the end of September. 
Now I will turn it back over to Steve, who will discuss our outlook.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. I'm pleased with our results this quarter and the strides we are making across our businesses in improving operating efficiency and offering customer-focused solutions. Our Corrugated Packaging business is performing very well. Box volumes a
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. I'm pleased with our results this quarter and the strides we are making across our businesses in improving operating efficiency and offering customer-focused solutions. Our Corrugated Packaging business is performing very well. Box volumes are growing and box pricing continues to be stable. Domestic containerboard market conditions are solid, and strengthening seasonally. Export market volumes continue to be strong and pricing is reasonable, considering the currency situation. Our mills and box plants are operating well. Folding carton demand is also solid and we're seeing strengthening in SBS and CRB markets and backlogs. 
Merger integration activity is going very well. We're on track to complete the merger in June. Our integration teams are working to ensure we can hit the ground running on day 1, that we achieve and drive to exceed our synergy targets. As we work together, we continue to identify new opportunities. I plan to give a more detailed summary of our synergy and performance improvement opportunities as well as our road map to achieve them on our July earnings call. 
Our new company will have a great business platform, strong cash flows and a solid balance sheet. Our capital allocation will center around a normalized leverage ratio of 2.25x to 2.5x. On day 1, our leverage ratio should be at approximately 2x, excluding the benefit of future synergies. Our leverage ratio is higher than both companies' current levels because we will be funding approximately $750 million at closing to repurchase the necessary RockTenn shares to reduce RockTenn's ownership interest of the new company to below 50%, and we will also use these funds for -- to pay deal-related transaction cost. With the strength of our balance sheet and underlying cash flows, we will have a balanced capital allocation strategy that will allow us to pay an attractive dividend; continue to invest in our business; take advantage of accretive business opportunity, including acquisitions; and return capital to our shareholders through share repurchases. 
We've considered postmerger dividend strategy. While that's a decision for the new board, I have some thoughts I will share with you now. We've had many conversations with shareholders over the last 3 months. As we always do, we listen. Our dividend policy should reflect that as a large-cap company with strong cash flows, we should pay an attractive dividend when compared to large-cap indices. When setting the dividend, we'll take into account the impact of the planned spin of Specialty Chemicals on our financial statements and also on our total market capitalization. I remain confident in the opportunities in front of us. This combination is a terrific opportunity to leverage the best of each company to create significant value for our customers and shareholders. 
As we expect to close on the merger this quarter, it's difficult to provide on guidance with respect to the reported results for the new company. The reported results will be a blend of both companies' results during the quarter. If you're looking for help in your modeling, I would guide you to RockTenn's adjusted EPS for the June quarter on a stand-alone basis being about 20% higher than the $0.85 we earned in the March quarter. 
Now with that, Jim, Mike, Ward and I are now ready to take your questions.

componenttext: I'd just -- the number we put out was $300 million for the synergies. We've done a substantial amount of work. I think we have talked about opportunities. And I think I would point out, when we get to July, I want to put in context both that $300 million but also in context the other productivity improvements that we have, so that you, as an analyst, can track our overall performance as a company. And that's the intent. I'm just -- the mechanics of doing that now, it's a little bit premature to provide that level of specificity at this point.
