headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're really pretty excited about the performance of our corrugated business. And the progress that we've made over the last number of months, we believe are solid and sustainable. Obviously, there's market variation that we have to adapt to. But we've do
componenttext: We're really pretty excited about the performance of our corrugated business. And the progress that we've made over the last number of months, we believe are solid and sustainable. Obviously, there's market variation that we have to adapt to. But we've done tremendous work at changing the culture of our corrugated business and investing in the assets and building a very execution-oriented manufacturing process and one focused on providing innovative solutions to our customers that we believe is being received very well. So I hope that gives some color that supports our view.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And Jim, I think last quarter you guys are talking about how in corrugated you're going to build some inventory in going to fiscal fourth quarter you're going to drive down. Can you provide any update on that front?
componenttext: Got you. And Jim, I think last quarter you guys are talking about how in corrugated you're going to build some inventory in going to fiscal fourth quarter you're going to drive down. Can you provide any update on that front?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the question is on containerboard inventories?
componenttext: So the question is on containerboard inventories?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if I heard you -- if I remember correctly last call, you mentioned you were going to build some inventory in fiscal 3Q and then draw it back down in fiscal 4Q. Any update on that front would be helpful.
componenttext: Yes, I think if I heard you -- if I remember correctly last call, you mentioned you were going to build some inventory in fiscal 3Q and then draw it back down in fiscal 4Q. Any update on that front would be helpful.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Exactly. Inventories are something that we micromanage, if you will, to ensure that we can provide adequate supply to our internal packaging operations as well as our customers. And we've just completed a large downtime quarter in the last quarter,
componenttext: Okay. Exactly. Inventories are something that we micromanage, if you will, to ensure that we can provide adequate supply to our internal packaging operations as well as our customers. And we've just completed a large downtime quarter in the last quarter, and so our inventories dropped as did the industry inventories dropped. As we reflect on inventories, in general, I know there's a lot perhaps on the comps for current industry inventories relative to the average 10-year inventories. And we just think that's really not apples-to-apples today. Examples being that we acquired the Smurfit-Stone assets in 2011, and they just had a very unsustainably low level of inventory that was not capable of providing our internal packaging operations. The ability to perform with appropriate on-time delivery and supply chain costs that were sustainable. And so we, today, focus our inventories on what is the optimal safety stock of doing supply chain math to try to manage that very crystally. And so we think inventories are at a sustainable level that is something that we will flex with changes in our mill operating uptime and the conditions in the market relative to rail and truck availability, et cetera.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And if I could sneak one in for Ward. If I heard you correctly, you're looking to potentially wrap up your leverage pretty quickly to that 2.25 to 2.5x. Is most of that going to be used for buybacks or maybe some cushion for M&A? How
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And if I could sneak one in for Ward. If I heard you correctly, you're looking to potentially wrap up your leverage pretty quickly to that 2.25 to 2.5x. Is most of that going to be used for buybacks or maybe some cushion for M&A? How should we think about that?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The 2.25 to 2.5x and our capital allocation strategies about balance. So we have the authorization in place to be able to go ahead and execute bond share repurchase, and we have the liquidity to do that and to take advantage of acquisition opportunit
componenttext: Yes. The 2.25 to 2.5x and our capital allocation strategies about balance. So we have the authorization in place to be able to go ahead and execute bond share repurchase, and we have the liquidity to do that and to take advantage of acquisition opportunities as they arise. So I think the message that we gave when we announced the strategy is it's putting up balance, and we'll be able to execute on any of the levers.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Mark Wilde from BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: Steve, I want just going back to this $1 billion number. If you can just give us a little color on how you think about sort of the interplay between sort of taking costs out and actually dropping that to the bottom line versus the just the ongoing cost reduction that you have to do stay competitive in the business.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Both of those factors are considered in the $1 billion. I think we've gotten some feedback that maybe the $1 billion might be wide. I think $1 billion is a lot of money. And if we can do that, that will be tremendous performance. And I think we are lookin
componenttext: Both of those factors are considered in the $1 billion. I think we've gotten some feedback that maybe the $1 billion might be wide. I think $1 billion is a lot of money. And if we can do that, that will be tremendous performance. And I think we are looking at trying to optimize the business. And I want to be able to grow the business overtime. And so that's the balance that we need to be looking at and will look at.

componenttext: From a margin standpoint. How much of that really is in margin and that you can retain a margin?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And Steve, just one other question for you. I've been with you a few times over the last 6 or 8 months where you've talked about the importance in transactions just getting the culture right from the get-go. You want to provide just a little color on what you're doing right now to get the culture right?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Invested a lot of time and integrating both organizations. I think both organizations are a lot more complementary and similar than, I think, a lot of people talk, but we're not taking it for granted. We're investing a lot of the management's time going o
componenttext: Invested a lot of time and integrating both organizations. I think both organizations are a lot more complementary and similar than, I think, a lot of people talk, but we're not taking it for granted. We're investing a lot of the management's time going out and identifying issues which are out there and we're addressing them. I'm very optimistic about the organization coming together. I preface the made an initial comment that we got enthusiastic alignment about the aspiration that we have for WestRock. And everywhere I've been, I've been a lot of places over the past several months, that resonates very clearly across the organization.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim or Steve, just one on containerboard. Jim or Steve you said I believe earlier that the line of linerboard is tight. We've seen the export data Crestline exports are up pretty significantly year-to-date and obviously, prices are down to some extent. So
componenttext: Jim or Steve, just one on containerboard. Jim or Steve you said I believe earlier that the line of linerboard is tight. We've seen the export data Crestline exports are up pretty significantly year-to-date and obviously, prices are down to some extent. So can you just kind of reconcile the statement that the linerboard market is tight with the significant increase we've seen in exports year-to-date?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, John.
componenttext: Go ahead, John.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen significant increases in export, and we have a very tight linerboard environment in North America. And our marketplaces the world we, of course, have a very strong position in the North American independent converter community, but we a
componenttext: Well, we have seen significant increases in export, and we have a very tight linerboard environment in North America. And our marketplaces the world we, of course, have a very strong position in the North American independent converter community, but we also sell to most countries of the world. And that's been our philosophy to try to diversify our mix to those markets, and we see solid demand in every one of them. Relative to the currency impact of a strong U.S. dollar, that does have pressure on price. The good news is, is that price hasn't dropped at par with the currency changes. And frankly, much of that change in currency-related price occurred in the last quarter of '14 -- over the last 2 quarters of '14 and really current year 3 quarters has been relatively solid. So we think much of that impact is gone. We're seeing strong markets in the world and prices firming.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, just one follow-up to that. I mean, I appreciate that the globe markets growing. But would you do -- are you surprised that exports are up Crestline board exports are up 9%? I wouldn't think that global demand would be growing at that kind of rate.
componenttext: Jim, just one follow-up to that. I mean, I appreciate that the globe markets growing. But would you do -- are you surprised that exports are up Crestline board exports are up 9%? I wouldn't think that global demand would be growing at that kind of rate.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: What we see is that virgin containerboard is very much in demand. The international markets of recycled containerboard, which trade at lower levels, the substitution has occurred. And so the growth in agricultural markets of the world are being fueled by
componenttext: What we see is that virgin containerboard is very much in demand. The international markets of recycled containerboard, which trade at lower levels, the substitution has occurred. And so the growth in agricultural markets of the world are being fueled by virgin containerboard. And so we don't see that surprising at all. In fact,, that's our underlying premise for being invest in that business.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one, OCC. Do have any thoughts long term as to where OCC is most likely to go? And what implication do you think that would have on North American containerboard industry competitive dynamics?
componenttext: And just one, OCC. Do have any thoughts long term as to where OCC is most likely to go? And what implication do you think that would have on North American containerboard industry competitive dynamics?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. We have tried to and always do build trend lines out into the future. And the only thing for certain is they're usually wrong. We see in the current marketplace that the global market has firmed. China has been somewhat sleepy for the last
componenttext: Great question. We have tried to and always do build trend lines out into the future. And the only thing for certain is they're usually wrong. We see in the current marketplace that the global market has firmed. China has been somewhat sleepy for the last number of months and quarters. For the last 3 months, there was some firming, however, it's softened again. So we think generally, the recovered fiber markets are firm, but we do not see any runaway trend occurring. Relative to long term, it's a global market, both wood and recovered fiber will likely have some upward inflationary trend. But we would guess those to be in balance as recovery rates increase globally and the marketplace plays out. To the question of North American competitiveness, we think the cost structure of the North American containerboard business is highly competitive with anywhere else in the world, and so we like our position.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Chip Dillon with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on all the hard work that I know has been going on for a long time. Thanks also for the update on the integration issue. It's interesting. It seems like you guys are probably among the larger players. And you can correct me, the least for
componenttext: Congratulations on all the hard work that I know has been going on for a long time. Thanks also for the update on the integration issue. It's interesting. It seems like you guys are probably among the larger players. And you can correct me, the least for integrated in the boxes. And yet we've seen this trend in the last couple years of independent box plants or at least, the sheet feeders that provide them being acquired by mill owners. And I didn't know if that's -- especially with last year's West Coast mill purchase, if that's something that you would consider as you think about growing the company, is more forward integration.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chip, yes, we would. I think we look at opportunities to improve our business, and that would pivot in that category.
componenttext: Chip, yes, we would. I think we look at opportunities to improve our business, and that would pivot in that category.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. And then could you talk a little bit about you've mentioned the tightness in craft linerboard. And basically reported that if you look just the craft linerboard, the U.S. capacity is actually lower today than it was 6 years ago. I'm sure pa
componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then could you talk a little bit about you've mentioned the tightness in craft linerboard. And basically reported that if you look just the craft linerboard, the U.S. capacity is actually lower today than it was 6 years ago. I'm sure part of that was due to the Smurfit-Stone shutdowns and the crisis. But nonetheless, we've seen a big competitor announce a small increase in their system capacity over the next few years. Do you feel that there are still actions you can take to free up craft linerboard capacity in your system? And I ask that because you've already done quite a bit of work on your system in the wake of the Smurfit-Stone deal.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we have opportunities to improve our overall system. It's kind of hard to speculate on what we do with respect to capacity going forward. I think in our $1 billion, we do have capital across our entire system to improve the operating performance.
componenttext: I think we have opportunities to improve our overall system. It's kind of hard to speculate on what we do with respect to capacity going forward. I think in our $1 billion, we do have capital across our entire system to improve the operating performance.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Ms. Debbie Jones with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help us understand your results in Brazil. I mean, you had a great quarter. Obviously, you're performing much better than the market. How much has to do with your competitive position in the investments that you've made down t
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help us understand your results in Brazil. I mean, you had a great quarter. Obviously, you're performing much better than the market. How much has to do with your competitive position in the investments that you've made down there?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it has a lot to do with the investments we've made. We had a very significant investment in the mill, and they have been knocking it out of the park. We've also focused on protein markets, which the product that we make have good success there. An
componenttext: I think it has a lot to do with the investments we've made. We had a very significant investment in the mill, and they have been knocking it out of the park. We've also focused on protein markets, which the product that we make have good success there. And we've expanded regionally on different areas of the country, which has given us just more position in the box market. That pretty much explains the performance. I will add all that doesn't occur without people, and I went very impressed with the organization we have in there. They fit extremely well into the overall WestRock system.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one follow-up. Pretty attractive dividend. How should we think about that going forward in terms of your dividend policy, whether it be progressive looking at payout or cover ratio?
componenttext: Okay. And just one follow-up. Pretty attractive dividend. How should we think about that going forward in terms of your dividend policy, whether it be progressive looking at payout or cover ratio?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Debbie. This is Ward. Although we haven't given out a payout ratio, we feel like we set a pretty attractive dividend compared to the S&P 500 index and competitive with our peers. We look at it in combination with our overall capital allocation strate
componenttext: Yes, Debbie. This is Ward. Although we haven't given out a payout ratio, we feel like we set a pretty attractive dividend compared to the S&P 500 index and competitive with our peers. We look at it in combination with our overall capital allocation strategy in the context of both our ability to invest in our business, take advantage of acquisition opportunities and then to also pursue share repurchases. The manage within the target leverage ratio so we -- I think we feel pretty comfortable with where we said in we think it's very attractive initial dividend level.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the sir Scott Gaffner of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the sir Scott Gaffner of Barclays.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to dig a little bit deeper on the projected synergy or overall cost savings run rate. I think you said you'd be at $150 million by the end of September on a run-rate basis. Is that just since July 1 or is that for the full fiscal year that y
componenttext: I just wanted to dig a little bit deeper on the projected synergy or overall cost savings run rate. I think you said you'd be at $150 million by the end of September on a run-rate basis. Is that just since July 1 or is that for the full fiscal year that you would get those -- to that run rate? And if that mostly around that SG&A savings?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what we started to do is we started to form the teams and do the planning. We started to evaluate cost from beginning of the calendar year. And so the accumulation of efforts that has been taking place. And just the -- remember, it's a combination of t
componenttext: So what we started to do is we started to form the teams and do the planning. We started to evaluate cost from beginning of the calendar year. And so the accumulation of efforts that has been taking place. And just the -- remember, it's a combination of the synergies and just beyond ongoing productivity efforts that we have across the whole organization. So what we did highlight is that we'll recognize a portion of the SG&A and infrastructure costs related to some of the duplicate corporate costs pretty quickly. And that is contributing to the run rate plus also the procurement synergies, we're doing -- we're moving very quickly on sourcing activities within combined WestRock, and we'll start to achieve some of those gains as we exit the calendar year.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when you look at the capital you outlined for 2016, the $850 million, anything you've identified maybe on the $500 million around potential capital avoidance where maybe some assets were over invested in? And maybe you can see that come down in
componenttext: Okay. And when you look at the capital you outlined for 2016, the $850 million, anything you've identified maybe on the $500 million around potential capital avoidance where maybe some assets were over invested in? And maybe you can see that come down in 2017?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. There might be some place, but I can't think of anywhere. We did given the circumstances do a very complete job of our capital planning. And we're very measured in our approach. And I think that's just what we came up with.
componenttext: No. There might be some place, but I can't think of anywhere. We did given the circumstances do a very complete job of our capital planning. And we're very measured in our approach. And I think that's just what we came up with.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And just lastly, given the combined entities only been together for about a month, have you had any customers come to you proactively around cross-selling opportunities where maybe you didn't have certain substrates before? Has that come to fruition yet or...

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob Beckler respond to that.
componenttext: Bob Beckler respond to that.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Scott, it's a great question. And it's been one of the pleasant surprises of the merger right out of the gates we're seeing all over with customer interest. It really falls into 3 categories. As you pointed out, just the sheer breadth of offer that we hav
componenttext: Scott, it's a great question. And it's been one of the pleasant surprises of the merger right out of the gates we're seeing all over with customer interest. It really falls into 3 categories. As you pointed out, just the sheer breadth of offer that we have in our packaging platform, corrugated, folding carton, beverage, packaging, dispensing systems and Merchandising Displays. Also, we have scale in all of these packaging segments, and so we're #1 or #2 in each of those that I just listed. And then finally, there's recognition that these have interplay, that they're connected, and so we're having a lot of dialogue with customers around how to connect together our capabilities, not just around the packaging product themselves, but our ability to work with them in their facilities to bring out the complete value that the packaging can offer. So summing it all up, the answer is a big yes, and we're very excited about the potential.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Anthony Pettinari with Citi.

componenttext: Okay, okay. And then just following up on Scott's question regarding the $1 billion target in performance improvements and your $850 million CapEx guidance for next year. componenttext: I think that's -- we're looking at a number of projects, and -- but I think they generally fit within the capital that we've had out there. I think we'll always look at our system and trying to find opportunities to be able to invest capital wisely. I think the premise is that we can do that within the capital that we outlined.

componenttext: Well, first, certainly, from an infrastructure point of view, there is. So there's the opportunity to consolidate data centers across the combined footprint. headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: And our next question comes from Mr. Chris Manuel with Wells Fargo.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick ones because I know we're deep in the call. But if I could come back to the -- you gave a capital outlook next year of $850 million and that's inclusive of the -- what you're doing this year for capital return projects and other elemen
componenttext: Just a couple quick ones because I know we're deep in the call. But if I could come back to the -- you gave a capital outlook next year of $850 million and that's inclusive of the -- what you're doing this year for capital return projects and other elements. What might the spend be to get the rest of the $1 billion? i.e, the other maybe $300 million of related synergies, et cetera? Should we think of something as 1 to 2-year or 2 to 3-year payback that's required to get those -- that comes out? So an idea of what other cost expenses are the next cadence of that for the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think within the $100 million, there's some of the expenses related to the IT projects that I described for which we'll be able to yield some meaningful savings, again data center, consolidation and other opportunities. I think the other components of i
componenttext: I think within the $100 million, there's some of the expenses related to the IT projects that I described for which we'll be able to yield some meaningful savings, again data center, consolidation and other opportunities. I think the other components of it are really of the $1 billion are the ongoing productivity programs that we have in both organizations that include investments in capital for return-generating projects. But then, within the $300 million, the 3 key components of the $300 million were mill and converting footprint optimization, SG&A and infrastructure cost reductions and then the procurement organization. So getting the leverage across the combined spend of the 2 companies. And so there really isn't a lot of other incremental cost inside the $100 million that we described. So we had severance-related costs. We had some capital related cost on the IT side.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So I guess, what I'm asking is -- I appreciate that. What I'm asking is to get that $300 million to savings, so for cash you're going to have good out the next 12 to 18 months for severance manufacturing optimization other pieces. Should we assume
componenttext: Right. So I guess, what I'm asking is -- I appreciate that. What I'm asking is to get that $300 million to savings, so for cash you're going to have good out the next 12 to 18 months for severance manufacturing optimization other pieces. Should we assume a 3-year payback that it's $100 million then? Or something like that? Or how should we think about that?

componenttext: So again...

So again, we described the -- so of the $100 million required to capture the synergies, we described a portion of it is going to be paid from the pension plan assets, and then the remainder of that will be paid, I think, over the course of the first 18 to 24 months of the integration.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kirsten. I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the WestRock Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, slides are being pres
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Kirsten. I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the WestRock Third Quarter Fiscal 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, slides are being presented today as part of the conference call. These slides can be accessed at www.westrock.com under the Investor page.
Ladies and gentlemen, this call is being recorded today, July 30. [Operator Instructions] Your speakers for today's call are Mr. Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer; and Mr. Ward Dickson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Voorhees, you may begin your conference.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to the first WestRock conference call. This is Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I appreciate you investing your time to learn more about our new company. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim P
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to the first WestRock conference call. This is Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I appreciate you investing your time to learn more about our new company. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging Solutions business.
During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discussed during the call. We described these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our WestRock S-4 filing and most recent 10-Ks and 10-Qs filed by our predecessor companies, RockTenn and MeadWestvaco. 
We will also refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation. The slide presentation is available on our website.
Since we announced the merger in January, we've been working on integrating the predecessor organizations into WestRock. We have enthusiastic alignment across the company about our aspiration to be the global industry leader in consumer and corrugated packaging markets, and we've made substantial progress in structuring our organization, externally, with our customers and suppliers and, internally, across our 275 operating and business locations around the world. We've identified and organized ourselves to capture the synergies and performance improvements that we have available to us from the merger and also from the momentum both organizations had going into the merger. We're very excited about the strength of our new company and the opportunity to create real value for our customers, stockholders and employees. I feel good about the progress we're making to develop the WestRock culture.
Of course, our success depends on delivering strong results. With that in mind, I'm turning to what we've done in the most recent quarter. Because the merger closed on July 1, we're not reporting consolidated WestRock results this quarter. We are reporting RockTenn's complete financial results for the June quarter. We're also reporting net sales and segment income information from MeadWestvaco. We don't plan to report the complete financial results of MeadWestvaco for the June quarter. I understand this may be of interest to the investment community. We chose not to maintain the administrative infrastructure and incur the expense necessary to report MeadWestvaco's complete financial results. The segment results show the detail regarding the current performance of our business, and we're providing details about the combined results of both companies in our new segment reporting structure.
We've accomplished a tremendous amount since announcing the merger 6 months ago, and I want to thank the WestRock team for maintaining our focus on serving our customers and operating very efficiently while, at the same time, working diligently on integration. The financial results in the June quarter for each predecessor company bear this out. RockTenn's adjusted EPS of $1.15 increased by 17% over last year. MWV segment income increased by 7%. Our combined segment income was up 10%. I'm particularly pleased with the strong returns in the WestRock Corrugated Packaging business in North America and Brazil. In our Consumer Packaging business, folding carton, food & beverage and home, health & beauty all performed well. 
For delivering on the envisioned benefits of our combination, at the time we announced the merger, we committed to a $300 million merger-related synergy target that represented approximately 7% of the revenue of MWV packaging business. This was on top of the approximate $700 million and the ongoing contribution the programs we already had in place to improve productivity through process improvement and capital investment. Going forward, we'll track the total $1 billion synergy and performance improvement target. 
The overall goal is more readily identifiable on our financial statements and will avoid the non-value-added effort of determining whether an individual action is merger or performance-related. We expect to reach the $1 billion target before the impact of inflation by the end of fiscal year 2018. This represents approximately 7% of our total revenue, excluding the Specialty Chemicals business. By the end of this September quarter, we expect to be at a run rate of $150 million in merger-related synergies and performance improvements.
An additional benefit of the merger is the ability to combine the overfunded MWV pension plans with the underfunded RockTenn plans. During the first week of July, we merged our U.S.-qualified pension plans. And as a result, we will avoid over $550 million in future pension contributions, including $40 million that would've otherwise been contributed on July 15. 
Our confidence in achieving our future cash flows supports our stockholder return strategy that we announced on July 1 and is comprised of $1.50 per share dividend and a 40 million share repurchase authorization that we intend to use to achieve our target leverage ratio of 2.25 to 2.50x. Our pro forma leverage at closing was right at 2x.
WestRock will report our results in 4 business segments. Corrugated Packaging will generate approximately $2 billion in quarterly sales and will include the RockTenn North American corrugated packaging business and recycling business and MWV Brazilian and Indian corrugated packaging businesses. At $1.7 billion in quarterly sales, Consumer Packaging will include RockTenn's consumer packaging and merchandising displays business and MWV's food & beverage and home, health & beauty businesses. Specialty Chemicals and Land and Development will continue as separate segments.
Sales of our Corrugated Packaging business are approximately $8 billion per year with the production of 8.5 million tons of a wide variety of paper grades. Of our 8 million tons of production in North America, our box plant system converts about 5 million tons per year into corrugated packaging. The remaining 3 million tons are sold to independent corrugated converters in North America and other international markets. 
We've operated an integrated system in Brazil for over 60 years. In 2013, we completed the $500 million investment, including a new paper machine to grow our Corrugated Packaging business. About 2/3 of our approximate 500,000 tons of production is converted in our own box plants. I visited these operations last month. I was very impressed with the quality of the assets and the outstanding team we have in place there.
Turning to the results for the June quarter for our combined Corrugated Packaging segment. Industry demand for corrugated packaging in the United States increased by 1.3% as measured by daily box shipments compared to last year. Exports grew by approximately 11% compared to last year. We exported 316,000 tons during the quarter, 30,000 tons more than both the March quarter and last year's quarter. Industry operating rates continue to be solid in the 96% range. We delivered very strong results in North America as measured by our 200 basis point EBITDA margin improvement to 19.4%.
The performance of our box plant system was a highlight of the quarter. Our volumes increased by 3.9% compared to last year. In July, we've maintained this performance. Box volumes are up 4% over last year. We continue to benefit from the cumulative impact of many areas of improvement executed by our team over the past 4 years, including quality and customer service. We're now halfway through the installation of 30 EVOL flexo folder gluers. Our results to date have exceeded our expectations.
Overall, corrugated box pricing in North America was up 0.6% as compared to the March quarter and down 1.5% compared to last year. Pricing of domestic containerboard increased about 1% on a sequential basis and also increased about 1% as compared to last year. Average export pricing declined by 1% from the March quarter and was down 8.5% compared to last year due to the strength of the U.S. dollar. Pricing for containerboard for export to Latin America remains stable.
Linerboard continues to be tight, but we've -- we have taken some economic downtime in medium to match our supply with our demand. During the June quarter, we took 104,000 tons of maintenance downtime and less than 20,000 tons of economic downtime. We expect only 4,000 tons of maintenance downtime in the September quarter.
Our recycling operation improved profitability during the quarter with segment income of $2.5 million after a loss in the March quarter of $400,000. This was a result of rising recycle prices and a strong operational cost focus. Consistent with recycling's primary mission of sourcing high-quality fiber for our mills, in June, the recycling group started exporting 6,000 tons per month to our India mills. This has improved fiber quality and reduced our delivered costs.
Turning to Brazil. Economic conditions remain challenging. While industry demand declined by 2%, we delivered outstanding results with box volume growth of 15% year-over-year. EBITDA margins of 28.7% were very strong, up 530 basis points compared to last year. We're seeing gains with major national meat and produce customers as well as growth in food oils and chemical markets. We were successful in raising prices to offset cost inflation.
The new containerboard machine in Brazil continues to operate extremely well. June quarter shipments of 125,000 tons set a record and were 7% higher than 1 year ago. We are integrating the North American containerboard export business with our export business in Brazil to increase our efficiency and the value we can provide to international customers.
Sales in our Consumer Packaging business are approximately $7 billion per year. Mill production is approximately 4 million tons of a wide variety of paper grades. All of our mill production is in North America. Our largest mill is Mahrt Alabama, which produces over 1 million tons of coated natural kraft. Our SBS system produces 2.1 million tons from mills in: Covington, Virginia; Demopolis, Alabama; Evadale, Texas; and La Tuque, Québec. We serve markets with high-quality requirements, including food and beverage, tobacco and commercial print markets. The recent acquisition of the Carolina-branded product line from International Paper improves our position in this attractive segment of the commercial print markets. Our recycled system includes 9 mills producing 1 million tons of coated and uncoated recycled paperboard. Our folding carton system consists of 34 plants across North America and Europe and generate sales of about $2 billion. 
The WestRock Consumer Packaging business includes our home, health & beauty dispensing business with approximately $600 million in sales. The combination of our dispensing business with our paper packaging businesses provides a unique, differentiated offering to these customers, and we're fully exploring these opportunities with our customers with very good success. Interestingly, the top 4 home, health & beauty customers account for more than $150 million in sales, and these same customers purchase 500 million of corrugated boxes, folding cartons and displays from WestRock.
Packaging has a very significant impact on our customer's success in their markets. The breadth, depth and scale of WestRock's Consumer and Corrugated Packaging solutions capabilities provides us with a unique opportunity to engage our customers to work together with us to help them be successful. Many of our customers are engaging with us on that very basis. I don't think any other company has the same opportunity, and I'm optimistic about what I've seen so far that I believe that we are and will be able to provide perspective, products and services that will support our customers' success and provide a runway of growth for WestRock.
Turning to the results for the Consumer Packaging segment. Overall industry mill operating rates are stable with CRB showing the greatest strength. Industry backlogs for CRB are 33% higher than last year, and our backlogs are approximately 4 to 5 weeks. We recently informed our customers of a $50 per ton price increase for CRB effective next month. Industry SBS backlogs have weakened since last year, and our system backlogs are at approximately 3 to 4 weeks. After a good beverage season, demand for coated natural kraft remains solid, and backlogs are roughly 4 to 5 weeks. 
The food and beverage business reported a 13% increase in income on flat sales and overcame currency headwinds that reduced sales by $22 million and income by $5 million. Beverage sales reflected volume growth and share gains in global beer that were offset by on-growing -- ongoing weakness in carbonated soft drink sales. All major regions, including North America, Europe and Asia, contributed to our overall sales growth in beverage. Our food business in the quarter was mixed with ongoing weak demand in the U.S. retail food markets. Despite this, we saw demand growth in food service, tobacco and selected retail food applications. During the quarter, we also began successfully onboarding the Carolina business and will transition to full production from International Paper at the end of the calendar year.
For the RockTenn consumer packaging system, sales were flat with last year while income increased by 11%. EBITDA margins improved by 140 basis points to 17.9%. Our converted volumes increased by 4% over the prior year as we captured new business, leveraging the manufacturing capabilities in our folding carton system. Over the last 18 months, we've started up new process on our: Knoxville, Tennessee; Nicholasville, Kentucky; and Clinton, Iowa plants.
Moving to our merchandising displays business. Industry demand for promotional displays are soft, driven by a number of factors, including the shift to the clean floor policy of a major retailer. Merchandising displays sales declined by 13% compared to last year. While income declined compared to last year, income more than doubled compared to the March quarter. We're working to match our cost structure to our anticipated levels of business through a number of actions, including streamlining our operations and have announced the closure of facilities in: Tullahoma, Tennessee; Chattanooga, Tennessee; and Lima, Ohio.
In the home, health & beauty system, income improved by 18% on lower sales, continuing the productivity improvement trends that we've seen for the past several quarters. Sales declined by 12% compared to the prior year, but decreased only 4% on a constant currency basis. The negative currency translation impact was expected as more than 30% of these sales are from Western Europe. The business executed very well commercially and operationally. We continue to gain volume in value-added segments, including fragrance and trigger sprayers.
Specialty Chemicals is a $1 billion business with EBITDA margins of over 25%. About 75% of the business produces performance chemicals, including asphalt additives, oilfield chemicals and a variety of other products. The performance chemical business adapts its refining process to changing market demand. As an example, when demand for oilfield chemicals has declined, we've been able to produce other products, including our asphalt additive products, to mitigate the impact of this change in market demand. The activated carbon business accounts for 25% of the segment revenue, has a very strong position in global automative -- automotive markets. The business has grown and sustained attractive profitability based on its consistent ability to identify opportunities and bring value-added solutions to market. 
We've been investing to expand capacity in Specialty Chemicals. Capital expenditures have been $100 million over the past 12 months, which includes our estimate of ongoing maintenance capital needs of $35 million per year. The most significant growth project has been in China, where we've invested in a greenfield activated carbon plant that will increase our capacity to serve the global automotive market by 15%. This plant will help us maintain our leadership in activated carbon, which is expected to grow with new more stringent global automotive emission requirements being phased in over the next several years.
As much as we like the Specialty Chemicals business, it's not core to WestRock, and we continue to work towards spinning this business off into a new company called Ingevity. We're well into our CEO search and expect to make an announcement in August. We intend to file the initial Form 10 in September. While we anticipate that we will be prepared to initiate the spin at the end of December, we're following guidance from our advisers that the best timing, from an equity capital markets perspective, will be to launch the spin-off to stockholders during the March quarter of 2016.
For the June quarter, Specialty Chemicals revenue declined 8%, but was down 4% on a currency-adjusted basis. Currency headwinds impacted the top line by $11 million. The business had record sales of asphalt additives and activated carbon in the quarter, partially offsetting weakness in oilfield chemicals and other markets. Our patented warm mix paving solution, Evotherm, had strong performance in the U.S. and Europe. Awareness of the performance and sustainability benefits of Evotherm continue to grow.
The activated carbon business remains strong with a growing portion of sales coming from higher-value solutions that address the more stringent automotive emission standards mandated by U.S. regulatory agencies that phase in beginning in 2017. Segment EBITDA margins were 26.7%. On a constant currency basis, EBITDA margins were 27.9%. The business continues to perform exceptionally well.
WestRock Land and Development is our legacy land development business, which, after entitling approximately 100,000 acres for development, selling over 1 million acres of timber and recreational land for over $2 billion over the last 8 years, is now focused on the value-added monetization of the remaining approximately 80,000 acres of development land, primarily located in and around Charleston, South Carolina. Most of the projects are held in partnerships with Plum Creek Land Company and others and are managed by WestRock.
Growth trends in the Charleston, South Carolina market are very positive. The Port of Charleston's growing. Boeing continues to expand its 787 manufacturing facility. Daimler Vans is building a new $500 million sprinter van manufacturing facility, which will employ 1,300 people, and Volvo recently announced the construction of a $500 million manufacturing facility that will employ 2,000 people. Last Friday, WestRock sold a 6,600-acre track for $34 million for Volvo's new manufacturing facility. It's nearby commercial and industrial land holdings and master-planned communities, including Nexton and Summers Corner, are well positioned to benefit from the on-growing -- ongoing regional growth around Charleston.
We expect these very favorable dynamics to support the acceleration of development land sales over the coming quarters. We're continuing to pursue the disciplined development of infrastructure and facilities necessary to match the increased demand for land from users, developers and homebuilders at a pace that maximizes value for stockholders.
WestRock will generate significant cash flow that will be available to be reinvested in the business or returned to stockholders. We have and will focus on capital allocations critical to our success, and we expect to have attractive opportunities to invest in our business. We've invested $1.8 billion in capital expenditures in our business during the past 2 years, including $865 million during the past 12 months. These investments include the new paper machine in Brazil, a new biomass boiler at our Covington, Virginia mill, a new woodyard in Florence, South Carolina, 15 new EVOL flexo folder gluers in our box plant system, the new activated carbon plant in China. WestRock stockholders are the beneficiaries of these investments.
We've recently completed our capital budget for fiscal year 2016. The capital budget process has included identifying projects including multiple lenses of: the market, our business strategy, the situation in individual locations. We've prioritized these projects by business and location in light of the aggregate fit with our business strategy. We plan to invest approximately $850 million in capital during fiscal 2016. We estimate maintenance capital to be $500 million. For the $350 million in return-generating projects, we expect to return unlevered after tax returns in the range of 20%.
The key return-generating capital projects in the paper solutions business are the Demopolis biomass boiler, the rebuild of the bark boiler at Mahrt, the carbonate cook project at the Stevenson, Alabama mill and the evaporator upgrade at the West Point, Virginia mill. Key return-generating projects within the packaging solutions group include: the installation of 7 additional EVOL flexo folder gluers in our box plants and 3 additional process at our folding carton plants, along with the conversion of our plant in the Czech Republic from tobacco to beverage operations. We'll make other investments in beverage and home, health & beauty to respond to specific customer requirements. Of the $850 million, about $35 million is for Specialty Chemicals in the December quarter prior to spin-off.
After investing the capital necessary to support and improve our business, WestRock will be able to return significant capital to stockholders. During the past 12 months, the combined companies paid $310 million in dividends and bought 265 million of stock. We would have bought back more stock had we not been prevented from doing so as a result of the merger. We've increased the annual dividend rate to $1.50 per share or $400 million, and we're in a position to buy back up to 40 million shares of stock to move to and maintain our target leverage ratio that's in the range of 2.25 to 2.50x.
I like the management team of the combined company. This group has come together extremely well, and we're working together effectively to move our company forward. As many of you know, our corporate management team, including me, our Chief Financial, accounting, human resource and sustainability officers as well as our general counsel, are all located in Norcross. Our Chief Communications and Chief Strategy Officers will be relocating to Norcross. We will continue to have a very significant presence in Richmond, which will be the location of our consumer paperboard, beverage and home, health & beauty businesses as well as the center of our research and development functions for the entire company and WestRock University, the center of our talent development activities.
The work that we've done on integrating the businesses, the work we've done on the dividend, share repurchases and the capital budget, the work we've done to put our organization in place, combined with the strong results we posted for the June quarter, provide us with a firm foundation and momentum as we enter the first year of WestRock.
I'll now turn the call over to Ward, and I'll come back after Ward's comments and wrap up the call. Ward?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Slide 14 is the RockTenn segment income bridge for the June quarter. We had strong growth in segment income with an increase of $32 million. The combination of price and mix was a negative $34 million, related primarily to the decline in
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Slide 14 is the RockTenn segment income bridge for the June quarter. We had strong growth in segment income with an increase of $32 million. The combination of price and mix was a negative $34 million, related primarily to the decline in export containerboard and pulp pricing over the last year. There has been some price and mix decline in box pricing over the last year, but only at approximately 1.5%. 
Cost deflation continued to be a benefit during the quarter with reductions on both recycled fiber and virgin fiber. Recycled fiber prices were down approximately 23% from last year. Our overall virgin fiber costs were down 3.8% from last year from a combination of lower prices, capital investments and the implementation over the last 2 years of our new wood-buying strategy.
We continue to make strong productivity gains, generating $31 million in benefit in the quarter with good momentum as we move to the $1 billion target for combined merger-related synergy and performance improvements. D&A, a noncash item, was $9 million unfavorable. Last year, we recognized a $9 million gain, recording previously unreported spare parts inventories.
MWV segment income improved by $14 million over last year despite the effects of currency. Cost deflation was a $12 million benefit with gains in energy, fiber and chemicals. Ongoing productivity and margin improvement programs created $21 million in higher earnings and provided good platform for our current initiatives. Pension income was $13 million lower on a quarterly basis.
Immediately after the merger announcement, we started on the integration analysis and preparation and developed detailed plans for every synergy opportunity. We engaged outside advisers to help us on certain areas. The $1 billion target includes both companies' specific cost-reduction and performance improvement targets of approximately $700 million and the merger-related synergies target of $300 million. Over 1/2 of the $1 billion target will come from our ongoing productivity and performance improvement programs across our manufacturing footprint and cost savings from capital investments, almost 30% will be from procurement opportunities and the remainder will be from manufacturing optimization and reductions from the elimination of duplicate corporate cost and support functions. The $1 billion performance improvement savings will be realized at about 1/3 over each of the next 3 years. We expect to realize a run rate of $150 million in savings by the end of September. The elimination of duplicate corporate expenses will be realized quickly. We have developed concrete plans behind each of these areas and have pushed the savings goals down to each business and function. Everyone will be held accountable for realizing these targets. 
Total transaction-related costs were approximately $115 million, and the estimated cost for us to capture the merger-related synergies are approximately $100 million. We estimate 20% to 30% of this will be paid from pension plan assets. I want to highlight that the $1 billion is before inflation. Labor benefits and insurance expense accounts for approximately $3.5 billion per year, and normal inflation on this category should be approximately $100 million per year. The balance of our inflation will depend on commodity price trends and could add another $125 million to $175 million in inflation per year. We will update the investment community on our progress against our target as part of our quarterly results. 
We bring a disciplined cost focus to the business and are instilling that view across 42,000 employees. We are currently rolling out allocations of the applicable corporate overhead costs to each business and call center, and we know from our past that it drives full accountability and visibility across the organization. By fully allocating costs, the businesses are able to challenge the corporate departments on their cost and spending, and management can determine where the best returns in investments should be made, if at all.
Our post merger balance sheet is very strong as opening leverage is approximately 2x and our maturities are very well spaced out. Both S&P and Moody's reaffirmed their ratings on WestRock at investment grade. Our $4.9 billion bank financing package has attractive terms and, combined with our other facilities, provides us with more than $3.5 billion of current available liquidity to execute on our disciplined and balanced capital allocation strategy. With leverage at 2x and our stock price at these levels, we have an opportunity to move rather quickly to increase our leverage toward our 2.25x to 2.5x leverage target. Our current debt mix is 62% fixed and 38% floating. Our combined average interest rate is about 4.7%. Our marginal cost to borrow on our available lines is less than 1.35%.
Before turning back to Steve, let me provide you an overview of some of the key assumptions that will help you in your modeling of our September quarter. Although our purchase price accounting work is not yet finalized, $270 million is our current estimate of depreciation and amortization for the fourth quarter. Of that, approximately $70 million is quarterly intangible amortization expense or $280 million on an annual basis. This will flow through our SG&A line and should be considered when making comparisons of our SG&A expense versus peers. We will do everything we can to drive unnecessary costs out of our business. For example, we are actively working to sublease the entire New York Park Avenue office space, and we'll seek to sublease currently available space enrichment. We're evaluating other opportunities to sublease available space across our company.
Effective with our July 2 pension plan margin, we are approximately 109% funded on a GAAP basis in our U.S. plans and are embarking on a derisking liability-driven pension investment strategy that is approximately 80% bonds. The corresponding expected return on the asset portfolio is 5.87%, which is reducing our forecasted pension income to about $8 million for the quarter. By moving immediately on merging the pension plans, we saved $14 million in pension contributions that would have been due on July 15.
We have provided a cost of goods sold breakout, which outlines our cost pools across our entire manufacturing footprint. In addition, we have provided 8 annual commodity consumption volumes to help you. The current estimated annual dollars spend across these 8 categories is approximately $2.8 billion. 
As we think about our foreign -- our exposure to foreign currencies, we look at our geographic revenue mix overall, which is 79% North American and 21% outside of this region. Of this 21%, approximately half is comprised of exports, of containerboard and paperboard that are priced primarily in U.S. dollars. The remainder is sold in local currency. Our largest foreign currency exposures are related to the euro and the Brazilian real. We estimate that a 10% strengthening of the dollar against these currencies would have a $30 million negative impact to EBT on an annual basis.
Back to you, Steve.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. Trends in most of our markets are stable to positive. This includes overall containerboard, paperboard and packaging markets while materials prices are also relatively stable. With respect to the outlook for the September quarter, we expect
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. Trends in most of our markets are stable to positive. This includes overall containerboard, paperboard and packaging markets while materials prices are also relatively stable. With respect to the outlook for the September quarter, we expect that the performance trends we have seen over the past quarter will continue and that our success in the quarter will be influenced by how we perform and maintain our momentum, including capturing the opportunities available to us as a result of the merger.
When we announced the merger on January 26, we said that, together, we're creating a global industry leader in consumer and corrugated packaging, a company with true competitive advantages, including an outstanding organization, a market-focused, customer-centric strategy and scale. We said that we'd be leveraging the strengths of both companies into a larger, more balanced and more global business, that the combined company would have an enhanced presence in the marketplace that will provide substantial opportunities for profitable growth. We said that we'd have the financial strength and flexibility to enable this growth.
All that remains true 6 months later. In fact, after 6 months, I feel even better about this combination, WestRock, than I did in January. We have a strong foundation and a near-term road map to capture the $1 billion in merger-related synergy and performance improvement opportunities by the end of fiscal 2018, and we're very focused on cash flow generation overall. Corrugated and Consumer Packaging are attractive businesses where scale and differentiation matter. We offer a set of products and services and scale that can't be offered by any other company. This provides us the opportunity to grow. We have the cash flow available to invest for growth on a disciplined basis and also the ability to return significant cash to stockholders via dividends and share repurchases. 
I want to thank you for your time and interest. We'll now turn the call over for Q&A. Operator, please open the lines.

componenttext: With the pension plan obviously, with the merger of the U.S. plans, we don't need to make contributions. We still have the partially unfunded pension plan in Canada, and we will be making contributions around $35 million in the year.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess first question I had for you, in past quarters, you've provided an earnings per share guidance for the upcoming quarter. I -- if you mentioned it here, I had missed it. If you didn't mention, I'm guessing it's because there's so many moving parts
componenttext: I guess first question I had for you, in past quarters, you've provided an earnings per share guidance for the upcoming quarter. I -- if you mentioned it here, I had missed it. If you didn't mention, I'm guessing it's because there's so many moving parts with writeups with the acquisition accounting, et cetera, that it may be as not fruitful for you to do that. Could you comment to that and whether you'll be providing quarterly earnings guidance on a going-forward basis? And then specific to the productivity goals and inflation. Would it be fair to assume that because of your actions that the labor inflation and, to some degree, even the commodity inflation should trend lower in years 2 and 3 of the program, such that you maybe get some widening of spread and improvement in earnings from that source?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: George, we didn't provide guidance, and you just hit the mark on why. And we just haven't come to a conclusion about whether we provide earnings guidance going forward. With respect to the labor question, Ward, do you have thoughts on that?
componenttext: George, we didn't provide guidance, and you just hit the mark on why. And we just haven't come to a conclusion about whether we provide earnings guidance going forward. With respect to the labor question, Ward, do you have thoughts on that?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I mean, if you look at the overall synergies and performance improvements within the $1 billion goal, labor is a component of it. We identified that the labor across the whole company, so that's both the SG&A pool and the manufacturing and i
componenttext: Well, George, I mean, if you look at the overall synergies and performance improvements within the $1 billion goal, labor is a component of it. We identified that the labor across the whole company, so that's both the SG&A pool and the manufacturing and indirect manufacturing expenses during the $0.5 billion per year. I -- it is a component of the synergy pool. But as you can tell, the largest individual item in the synergy pool is the procurement savings that we're going to have by having that combined leverage of the 2 companies. So I think trying to project what inflation and commodity price movements are going to be over the 3-year period is hard. We just tried to put a stake in the ground for you.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Ward, if I can just a follow-on, just on the guidance and I'll turn it over. Historically, the fourth fiscal quarter was RockTenn's largest quarter. Would there be anything now in terms of the mixture of the 2 businesses, supply chain, what have you
componenttext: Okay. Ward, if I can just a follow-on, just on the guidance and I'll turn it over. Historically, the fourth fiscal quarter was RockTenn's largest quarter. Would there be anything now in terms of the mixture of the 2 businesses, supply chain, what have you, such that, that would not be the case again, recognizing that there are going to be lots of moving parts in this particular quarter?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as we look at the underlying performance of the business, some of the trends that Steve highlighted, I would say that we're seeing continue into the fourth quarter. We will start to recognize some of the initial synergies related to some of t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as we look at the underlying performance of the business, some of the trends that Steve highlighted, I would say that we're seeing continue into the fourth quarter. We will start to recognize some of the initial synergies related to some of the corporate overhead pools. But again, the primary reason that we described for not giving guidance in the quarter was that we -- truly, we want to close the books for a month. We've got a lot of moving pieces, as you described, with the opening balance sheet and the consolidation.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Philip Ng.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: You've outpaced the market pretty nicely on the Corrugated side. How sustainable is that? And do you start comping that benefit in Q4? And any color in terms of how trends are shaking out in July would be great.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're really pretty excited about the performance of our Corrugated business, and the progress that we've made over the last number of months, we believe, are solid and sustainable. Obviously, there's market variation that we have to adapt to. But we've d
componenttext: We're really pretty excited about the performance of our Corrugated business, and the progress that we've made over the last number of months, we believe, are solid and sustainable. Obviously, there's market variation that we have to adapt to. But we've done tremendous work at changing the culture of our Corrugated business and investing in the assets and building a very execution-oriented manufacturing process and one focused on providing innovative solutions to our customers that we believe is being received very well. So I hope that gives some color that supports our view.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And Jim, I think last quarter, you guys are talking about how, in Corrugated, you were going to build some inventory, and going to fiscal fourth quarter, you're going to drive down. Can you provide any update on that front?
componenttext: Got you. And Jim, I think last quarter, you guys are talking about how, in Corrugated, you were going to build some inventory, and going to fiscal fourth quarter, you're going to drive down. Can you provide any update on that front?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the question is on containerboard inventories?
componenttext: So the question is on containerboard inventories?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if I heard you -- if I remember correctly, last call, you mentioned you were going to build some inventory in fiscal 3Q and then draw it back down in fiscal 4Q. Any update on that front would be helpful.
componenttext: Yes. I think if I heard you -- if I remember correctly, last call, you mentioned you were going to build some inventory in fiscal 3Q and then draw it back down in fiscal 4Q. Any update on that front would be helpful.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, exactly. Inventories are something that we micromanage, if you will, to ensure that we can provide adequate supply to our internal packaging operations as well as our customers. And we've just completed a large downtime quarter in the last quarter,
componenttext: Okay, exactly. Inventories are something that we micromanage, if you will, to ensure that we can provide adequate supply to our internal packaging operations as well as our customers. And we've just completed a large downtime quarter in the last quarter, and so our inventories dropped as did the industry inventories dropped. As we reflect on inventories, in general, I know there's a lot of preps on the comps for current industry inventories relative to the average 10-year inventories, and we just think that's really not apples-to-apples today. Examples being that we acquired the Smurfit-Stone assets in 2011, and they just had a very unsustainably low level of inventory that was not capable of providing our internal packaging operations. The ability to perform with appropriate on-time delivery and supply chain costs that were sustainable. And so we, today, focus our inventories on what is the optimal safety stock of doing supply chain math to try to manage that very crystally. And so we think inventories are at a sustainable level that is something that we will flex with changes in our mill operating uptime and the conditions in the market relative to rail and truck availability, et cetera.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And if I could sneak one in for Ward. If I heard you guys -- if I heard you correctly, you're looking to potentially ramp up your leverage pretty quickly to that 2.25 to 2.5x. Is the -- is most of that going to be used for buybacks o
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And if I could sneak one in for Ward. If I heard you guys -- if I heard you correctly, you're looking to potentially ramp up your leverage pretty quickly to that 2.25 to 2.5x. Is the -- is most of that going to be used for buybacks or maybe some cushion for M&A? How should we be thinking about that?

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The 2.25 to 2.5x and our capital allocation strategy is one about balance. So we have the authorization in place to be able to go ahead and execute upon the share repurchase, and we have the liquidity to do that and to take advantage of acquisition o
componenttext: Yes. The 2.25 to 2.5x and our capital allocation strategy is one about balance. So we have the authorization in place to be able to go ahead and execute upon the share repurchase, and we have the liquidity to do that and to take advantage of acquisition opportunities as they arise. So I think the message that we gave when we announced the strategy is it's one of balance, and we'll be able to execute on any of the levers.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Mark Wilde from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Steve, I wonder, just going back to this $1 billion number, if you can just give us a little color and how you think about sort of the interplay between sort of taking costs out and actually dropping that to the bottom line versus the just ongoing cost reduction that you have to do stay competitive in the business.

headline: Rock-Tenn Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Both of those factors are considered in the $1 billion. I think we've gotten some feedback that maybe the $1 billion might be wide. I think $1 billion is a lot of money. And if we can do that that'll be tremendous performance. And I think we are looking a
componenttext: Both of those factors are considered in the $1 billion. I think we've gotten some feedback that maybe the $1 billion might be wide. I think $1 billion is a lot of money. And if we can do that that'll be tremendous performance. And I think we are looking at trying to optimize the business, and I want to be able to grow the business over time. And so that's the balance that we need to be looking at and will look at.

componenttext: From a margin standpoint. How much of that really is in margin and that you can retain in margin?
