headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to WestRock's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. The material for today's call will be available on the company's website, www.westrock.com. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this
componenttext:
Welcome to WestRock's Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. The material for today's call will be available on the company's website, www.westrock.com. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point.
I'll now turn the meeting over to Mr. Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. Sir, you may begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning. This is Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. Thanks for taking the time to listen to our call today. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob
componenttext:
Thanks. Good morning. This is Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. Thanks for taking the time to listen to our call today. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging Solutions business.
We're looking forward to sharing our results for the September quarter of 2015, which is the first quarter for which we're reporting the results of WestRock.
During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We described these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, these include our WestRock S-4 filing, the most recent 10-Ks and 10-Qs filed by our predecessor companies, the recent Form 10 filed to enable the tax spend of our Specialty Chemicals business.
We will refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. You may have noticed in our press release on Page 19 of our earnings call deck that we've provided a comparison of our results for the September quarter of 2015 to the September quarter of 2014. This comparison is the reported results of predecessor companies as adjusted for our new segment and other merger-related accounting items, including application of a consistent method for allocating corporate cost. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation that's available on our website.
We've performed well in our first quarter of operations as WestRock. The most appropriate place for me to start is by thanking all of my WestRock coworkers who have continued to take care of our customers, operate safely and deliver strong results in a competitive business environment. All are working extremely hard to take advantage of the many opportunities that we have the newly merged company. We continue to have enthusiastic alignment across the company about our aspiration to be the global industry leader in consumer and corrugated packaging markets. We're making significant strides in areas that are driving value from the merger, including the integration of our organizations, the realization of the merger-related synergies and performance improvements and the opportunities we have to provide a broad range of paper and packaging solutions to help our customers succeed in their markets.
We reported $0.93 of adjusted earnings per share and generated $268 million of free cash flow after adding back the after-tax cost of transaction fees and restructuring cost.
We executed exceptionally well in our packaging businesses. Our North American box business increased volumes by 2.9% on a per day basis in the quarter. This compares to a less than 1% increase for the industry over the same time frame. Our containerboard mill system is operating efficiently. The North American Corrugated Packaging business earned adjusted EBITDA margins of 20%. The Corrugated Packaging business in Brazil is operating exceptionally well and earned adjusted EBITDA margins of 28% in the September quarter.
Our consumer mill system is also operating well, and published price increases across the recycled grades. There's positive momentum in folding carton the merchandising displays, and I'll have more color on each of those shortly.
Specialty Chemicals sales of activated carbon and asphalt additives were at record levels, but those gains were more than offset by lower sales to oilfield drilling and industrial markets. EBITDA margins were 24.9%. And initial Form 10 was filed on October 6. We're targeting an approximate March 1, 2016, spin date.
We're progressing toward our $1 billion in annualized synergy and performance improvements to be achieved by the end of fiscal 2018. We generated annualized run rate savings at quarter-end in excess of $150 million, and we expect annualized run rate savings of at least $400 million by the end of fiscal year 2016.
We're executing on our disciplined and balanced capital allocation strategy. We ended the quarter at 2.08 leverage, slightly under our stated target leverage ratio of 2.25 to 2.5x.
We completed the SP Fiber acquisition on October 1. The Dublin, Georgia mills an excellent asset and provides a valuable product mix and adds logistical flexibility within our system. The and newsprint and containerboard machines were idled in our first month of operation due to market conditions in this front and our need to balance supply and demand in our containerboard mill system. We continue to expect performance improvements in excess of $50 million over 3 years for the transaction to be accretive in the second half of fiscal 2016.
On October 12, we announced the formation of a joint venture with Grupo Gandhi for our packaging businesses in Mexico. Gondi is a high-quality paperboard manufacturer and packaging converter for many local and global brand-name customers. Our partnership will help grow our presence in the attractive Mexico market. We expect to begin operations as a joint venture as soon as we receive Mexican regulatory approval, which we expect will take 4 to 6 months.
We repurchased approximately 5.4 million shares in the quarter at an average price of $60.20. We were and continue to be limited in the number of shares we can buy as a result of our need to maintain at least a 50.1% ownership interest by legacy MWV stockholders as of July 1, 2015. This continuity of ownership is necessary to preserve the tax-free separation of the Specialty Chemicals business from WestRock. We have been and are able to buy back shares up to the exact overlapping investor ownership of our predecessor companies at the specific funnel level as of July 1. We have sufficient repurchase opportunity available to us to operate within our target leverage ratio range.
I will now provide more details on our overall results and performance in each business segment before turning it over to Ward, and then I'll come back to provide thoughts on the outlook for our December quarter.
When we compare WestRock's results in the September quarter to the combined recast results in the same quarter of last year, sales declined by $203 million or 5%. This decline was largely comprised of $141 million of unfavorable foreign currency translation and $44 million of revenue from the European tobacco converting business sold earlier in the year. Adjusted segment EBITDA, net of corporate cost, declined by $80 million compared to last year due to foreign currency translation impact of $26 million. The absence of the $23 million gain we recorded last year due to the write up of spare parts inventory in our mill system and $26 million in lower pension income. WestRock's credit agreement EBITDA and EBITDA margins over the last 12 months are in excess of $2.5 billion and 16.9%, respectively.
Let's turn to each of our segments.  WestRock's Corrugated Packaging team performed well in the September quarter, especially considering the headwinds we faced in the quarter from a weaker global economy and a stronger U.S. dollar. Net sales declined by $75 million or 3.7%. On a constant currency basis, sales were up by $20 million or 1%. Of the $95 million in currency headwinds, about 1/2 was in Brazil, 1/3 was due to the Canadian dollar and most of the rest was Mexican peso. Segment income was lower by $39 million, with $23 million of that related to the write up of spare parts last year and $15 million related to currency impacts in Canada, Brazil and India.
Overall segment EBITDA margin was 19.4%. Our North American corrugated margin of 20% and our Brazil margin at 28%. As I referenced earlier, our North American box volumes increased by 2.9% compared to last year, and box pricing in North America was stable. Our box systems have been very successful in the market by focusing on quality and on-time delivery in combination with innovation that's relevant to our customers' needs. This approach has enabled us to retain existing customers and grow our customer base over time, including gains in the quarter with customers for protein and processed foods, snacks, dairy and e-commerce. Our success has been and will be defined by how well we operate on a day-to-day basis in each of our plants and with each of our customers. The scale of the WestRock organization has supported our local success to our capital investment, our investment in people and connecting our coworkers so as to make it easier to share knowledge on how to succeed across the company and with our customers.
We've continued our volume growth in October by increasing sales on a per day basis by more than 3% over last year. Our North American corrugated shipments in the quarter declined by 15,000 tons compared to the June quarter and 57,000 tons or 2.7% compared to last year. Export volumes declined by 29,000 tons compared to last year. Our overall export pricing declined $9 per ton compared to the June quarter and $37 per ton compared to last year.  Prices of containerboard to third-party domestic customers have been within a $5 per ton range since the summer of 2014.
We took approximately 76,000 tons of downtime during the quarter, all except 3,000 tons being economic downtime. In October, we took about 95,000 tons of downtime in our corrugated mill system with approximately 55,000 tons being economic downtime, the remainder being maintenance downtime at our Florence mill.
We've consistently operated our system in a way that balances production with our customer demand. We plan and schedule this balance on an ongoing basis and take actions as needed, including slowbacks, economic downtime, maintenance downtime and permit closures. Our goal is to pursue the actions that we believe will optimize our mill system, thus producing the best economic and operating results for WestRock and our customers. We don't publicly announce our actions. We communicate our plans to the employees, customers and suppliers who'll be most directly impacted. This past month is an example of this planning and execution, which we took actions at several facilities. With the October 1 completion of the SP Fiber transaction, we were able to reassess our overall mill system to determine the optimal way to meet our customer demand. Following this assessment, we announced indefinite downtime at both and ville to immediately match our production to customers' orders. The following week, we announced the permanent closure of the 310,000-ton Ohio mill, which will occur in late November to provide an orderly mill closure and consumption of raw materials, such as chemicals, wood and recovered fiber. The closure of will reduce our annual operating cost by $33 million and avoid an additional $4 million annually in maintenance capital expenditures.
The same week, we announced an indefinite idling of our new board mill due to the unprofitable nature of the newsprint business and an inadequate order book of containerboard and bad grades. The mill will be idled in mid-November. We retain the optionality on the 2 excellent paper machines at Newburgh in the event West Coast demand warrants a restart. All these actions have been well planned and executed and went according to our expectations. When we take economic downtime, we communicate that it is indefinite because the period of downtime may change with market conditions or lead to a permanent closure.
We will continue to operate our system focused on our customers. Our plans to take -- our plan is to take 114,000 tons of maintenance downtime in our corrugated mills during the December quarter. The from being of each paper machine has been restarted and the ville mill is being restarted mid-month as planned to meet our customer demand. We're currently operating with 56,000 tons more inventory than we operated with 1 year ago. This additional inventory has helped improve on-time delivery and customer satisfaction, with both our internal and external box plant customers, and it's also reduced logistics cost. This benefit far outweigh the carrying cost of increased investment and inventory. Based on our forecasted sales in major maintenance and capital downtime plan, our containerboard inventories will gradually build an additional 30,000 tons from the end of September till they peak in the January, February time frame, then we would expect them to return to our current level over the following few months.
In Brazil, the economic situation continues be challenging, and our great team in the regions managed to continue to deliver very strong results, including adjusted EBITDA margins of 28.2% and sales growth of 10% on a local currency basis. Our industry box demand declined by more than 5%. We grew box volume by 3% year-over-year with strength in protein, produce and export markets.
In September, our mill in Brazil set new production and shipment records. The interaction between our North American Brazilian corrugated teams has benefited both businesses, so we've been able to drive improved productivity at our mills and box plants.
In 2016, GDP in Brazil is expected to decline by approximately 2%, and industrial production is expected to decline by approximately 6%. Our corrugated business in Brazil is not immune to these challenges. We expect to continue to perform well due to our high-quality assets, customer service and the differentiation of our virgin-based paper and packaging offerings.
In the Consumer Packaging segment. Overall results reflect good commercial and operational execution in the face of some difficult macro headwinds related to the stronger U.S. dollar. Net sales in the segment declined $140 million or 8% when compared to last year. This includes $37 million of negative impact from currency. Adjusted segment EBITDA was $14 million lower due to $8 million of foreign exchange impact and $4 million from the sale of the European tobacco business. Segment EBITDA margins were 15.6%.
In the paperboard markets, our SBS group service volumes grew, and our folding carton and food markets are doing well. Industry SBS backlog are 393,000 tons, somewhat lower than the 454,000 tons the same time last year. Our backlogs are 3.5 weeks.
We're making very good progress integrating the Carolina brand that we acquired earlier this year. Sales during the quarter were at a rate equivalent to 180,000 tons per year. We expect to fully transition manufacturing to our facilities by the end of December. One of the first opportunities from the merger was to integrate SBS tons into our folding carton system, and we're already more than halfway to achieving a full annual run rate of 50,000 tons by the end of December. During the quarter, these domestic SBS shipments more than offset softer exports for tobacco and liquid packaging grades.
Industry backlogs for coated recycle board remained strong at approximately 165,000 tons, which is more than 40% higher than this time last year. WestRock CRB backlogs are greater than 4% -- 4 [ph] weeks. We're moving production of our millennium board product from our Dallas and Stratford mills to the Mahrt mill. We're backfilling both Galveston with additional CRB business. Demand for CMK remains solid, and our backlogs are nearly 4 weeks. Those shipments grew by more than 3%, supported by growth from our beverage system.
In North America, we largely offset declines in carbonated volumes with gains with our larger brewer customers, continued growth with kraft brewers and gains in the word. In Europe, we saw stronger sales with our larger brewer customers. On the Asia Pacific region, we saw improvement in carbonated soft drinks and dairy packaging.
Our broader folding carton business also performed extremely well. We shared gains in new business in categories such as on-the-go foods, offsetting declines in areas such as cereal. Our general folding carton volumes were up 2% during the quarter, a fifth straight quarter of year-over-year growth. Our operational performance in our carton facilities was also strong with better plant loading and efficiency gains. Our home, health & beauty business improved income and margins due to favorable mix from sales of trigger sprayers and health care dispensing systems as well as productivity gains.
And then our Merchandising Displays business, we saw a strong rebound with quarterly earnings up 55% over the prior year. After a challenging year that included some sales decline, we're seeing signs of growth and a strengthening market for promotional displays. Our decisions over the last couple of years to strategically invest capital to lower our cost has had a significant positive impact. We've invested in our innovation platform and that's supporting our growth in new markets, including recently earning awards of new business that helped in the year in a very positive work. Many of our customers are learning more about our capabilities. We've taken advantage of these opportunities to discuss our full product line and to learn about our customers' objectives, so we can develop paper and packaging solutions that help our customers meet their objectives.
Specialty Chemicals business continues to perform well in the face of the slowdown in drilling and other industrial activity. Adjusted EBITDA margins remain very attractive at 24.9%, even as sales declined by $26 million compared to last year. Integrity is starting up a new activated carbon plant in China this quarter and expanding our chemicals plant in Brazil at the first of the year. The activated carbon plant in China will provide needed capacity for our global system that supports the growing automotive sector.
We're making good progress in qualifying the new production with our automotive customers in Asia and beyond and expect sales to ramp up in the first half of next year.
The December quarter is seasonally the softest quarter for Specialty Chemicals. This is principally due to the winter slowdown in road-paving activity. We expect continued challenges in the oilfield sector, which impacts the segment sales levels and margins.
I'm very pleased that both Michael Wilson and John Fortson have joined Longevity as CEO and CFO, respectively. They both bring tremendous and highly relevant experience to the business. We have confidence in their ability to lead Longevity through these challenges and growth as an independent company.
The spinoff of Longevity is moving forward. The initial Form 10 was filed, and we're targeting an approximate March 1, 2016 spin date.
The Land and Development business continues to make good progress on their major projects in the Charleston region. The business had a fantastic quarter from a revenue standpoint with $45 million in revenue, including a $34 million gain related to the 68 -- I mean, the sales for $34 million related to the 6,800-acre site that Volvo acquired to build their new U.S. manufacturing facility. But due to the impact of purchase price accounting, we're revaluing their existing projects to fair value. They lost $3 million on a GAAP basis. The step-up in book value had a $15 million negative impact on segment income in the quarter. This marketing to fair market value of our land portfolio in this business will reduce future profitability on existing projects, but it does not impact future cash flows. As part of the valuation work, we have developed a project-by-project valuation of the partnership, which for our share, is over $400 million. The experienced team in this business is executing on a plan to maximize this potential value. We're considering ways to monetize that value at a faster pace.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ward Dickson. Ward?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Looking at our segment EBITDA, the productivity initiatives we have in place are working to offset inflation and FX. Productivity and synergies drove $60 million in earnings improvement. FX was a negative $26 million headwind, which with
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Looking at our segment EBITDA, the productivity initiatives we have in place are working to offset inflation and FX. Productivity and synergies drove $60 million in earnings improvement. FX was a negative $26 million headwind, which with much of that in Europe and Brazil. And the total impact of inflation of labor and commodities for the segments and corporate was $20 million. The change in labor and benefits was approximately $29 million, and there was $9 million of combined deflation in commodity and other cost categories.
The total impact of price and mix changes was minimal in the quarter. Corrugated Packaging had positive price/mix variance in due -- in part due to domestic box pricing, higher prices in Brazil, lower volumes of exports and domestic tons shipped and an increase in higher-margin box shipments. There was some decline in price and mix in the Consumer Packaging grades and Specialty Chemicals.
Noncash pension income was $26 million lower than last year due to, among other things, lower return on asset assumptions as we de-risked our pension plans; the nonrecurring amount of $29 million includes $23 million from last year's spare parts gains that didn't recur this year.
We made significant progress during our first quarter as WestRock toward our $1 billion synergy and productivity improvement target. We entered the quarter at a run rate of $75 million in savings and exited at an annualized run rate in excess of $150 million, which exceeded our expectations at the beginning of the quarter. This is a significant objective that will take a lot of work over the next 3 years to capture. Our entire organization is focused on meeting these objectives, and we have consistent monitoring and processes in place to make sure we stay on track, so we are confident in our ability to reach $1 billion by the end of fiscal 2018. We estimate that we will be at an annualized run rate of at least $400 million by the end of the fiscal year 2016.
Our total SG&A costs for the quarter were $429 million or 11% of sales. However, this total includes $64 million in ongoing merger and acquisition-related intangible amortization cost that flow through the $281 million depreciation and amortization line on our cash flow. Excluding intangible and amortization, our SG&A costs are running at 9.4% of sales and will trend lower as we execute on our synergy and performance improvement program.
We have completed our work to allocate corporate cost to the appropriate business units, all the way down to the cost in our level. The full cost allocation brings further visibility into spending and business unit profitability. When comparing legacy RockTenn and MWV, approximately 70% of RockTenn's corporate costs were allocated to the business units and MWV was approximately 30% allocated. There was also some geography changes in the allocation work as some legacy MWV manufacturing site costs were nonproduction activities in the amount of $18 million removed from cost of goods sold to SG&A. And as Steve said, we have included Slide 19 that provides a reconciliation of reported to recast segment income and EBITDA for Q4 FY '14 for comparability purposes.
We ended the quarter with $5.6 billion in recorded debt, and included in that figure is approximately $340 million in fair value step-up to the market value of the legacy MWV debt. The notional amount of what we owe under our debt obligations are approximately $5.3 billion. Our balance sheet is in great shape as we have $3.4 billion in available liquidity to support our strategy and very few maturities over the next several years. Our leverage ratio ended the quarter at 2.08x.
Our pension plans are in great shape, and we ended the fiscal year with almost $400 million in combined GAAP-funded status surplus in our qualified U.S. and Canadian pension plans. The U.S. plans were overfunded by more than $500 million, and the Canadian plans were underfunded by more than $100 million. The overfunding in the U.S. plans gives us options as we think about de-risking our balance sheet.
Slide #13 has a number of key financial items to help in modeling our performance. Depreciation and amortization will continue to be approximately $285 million on a quarterly basis. And of that total, intangibles amortization is approximately $70 million. Our CapEx is still estimated at $850 million for the full year. The pension income of $8 million represents both the qualified and nonqualified plan amounts. Our books -- our book tax rate should be in the range of 33% to 35% for the December quarter. The September quarter effective tax rate of 29% was lower than our forecast due to discrete items, primarily at the state tax level.  We are planning scheduled maintenance downtime within our corrugated mill system of 114,000 tons during the quarter.
Other items incorporated in our tax position also included $21.5 million of nontax deductible restructuring fees. Cash spent into contributions into our qualified pension plans are approximately $37 million in fiscal 2016 with almost all of that going into our Canadian plans. Our nonqualified Orser plans will require additional cash funding of approximately $13 million this fiscal year. We have $115 million in state federal and foreign NOLs and $213 million in AMT and other federal credits.
And now I'll turn it back over to Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. Looking to the immediate future, there's a number of items that will impact our performance in the December quarter as compared to the September quarter. We're seeing benefits from our performance improvement initiatives. Our domestic box an
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. Looking to the immediate future, there's a number of items that will impact our performance in the December quarter as compared to the September quarter. We're seeing benefits from our performance improvement initiatives. Our domestic box and folding carton businesses continue to do well compared to the market. Energy prices are lower, which is a positive for us. There's 3 less shipping days this quarter, and the December quarter historically has lower seasonal sales volumes than the September quarter. Maintenance and economic downtime will have negative earnings impact. The euro and Brazilian real have both softened from September averages, and we expect return to normal tax rates. Considering all of these items in the quarter, we expect sales and earnings to be lower in the December quarter as compared to last quarter.
Looking further out, WestRock aspires to be the global leader in corrugated and consumer packaging. The first step for WestRock to achieve this aspiration is to combine and integrate our organizations and in the process, capture $1 billion in merger-related efficiencies and productivity improvements. We're on the road to capture this opportunity over the next 3 years. We've made a lot of progress in our business in just 4 months. We've made progress building our culture at WestRock, progress making our operations more efficient and more importantly, progress teaming with our packaging customers to grow their share in the marketplace. While paper and packaging are very attractive businesses, the global economy, a strong U.S. dollar, intense competition challenges across our businesses. We're responding to these challenges with urgency, both to deliver short-term results, but also to keep our eye on the long-term opportunity we have within our sights. I remain enthusiastic about the opportunities that are ahead of us and believe we're making excellent progress in the long-term value creation opportunities we have as WestRock.
That concludes our prepared remarks. Jim, Bob, Ward and I are now ready to take your questions. Operator?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: My 2 questions are going to center around consumer. I guess the first question I had broadly, is there a way to quantify what kind of benefit you expect to get from the insourcing of Carolina? And for that matter, the integration benefit you mentioned in
componenttext: My 2 questions are going to center around consumer. I guess the first question I had broadly, is there a way to quantify what kind of benefit you expect to get from the insourcing of Carolina? And for that matter, the integration benefit you mentioned in carton, I think, it was something to the tune of 50,000 tons and how that will begin to play out in the quarters.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The integration of Carolina, we're going to begin producing those as rapidly as we can. We think we'll be up by the December quarter. So right now, we're at a run rate of 180,000 tons. We'll take the incremental benefit of that tons to incremental margin.
componenttext: The integration of Carolina, we're going to begin producing those as rapidly as we can. We think we'll be up by the December quarter. So right now, we're at a run rate of 180,000 tons. We'll take the incremental benefit of that tons to incremental margin. Just don't really speak to pricing and margin with respect to that. And it's pretty much the same strong segment [ph] versus folding carton business. I think we have integrate that, I think, in October. We, in fact, have integrated 4,000 to 5,000 tons into our system already. So we're well underway to the 50,000 tons. We set in the comps we'll be at 50,000 tons by the end of December.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: We said we'd be there by the end of the quarter. I saw some information October. I think we're just about there now. But -- so but close to the end of the quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question, again, around consumer. A couple of parts to it. With carton volumes up and merchandising strong, certainly model do you think that we're finally seeing the pickup in the consumer we've been waiting for? It seems like for a long tim
componenttext: Okay. Second question, again, around consumer. A couple of parts to it. With carton volumes up and merchandising strong, certainly model do you think that we're finally seeing the pickup in the consumer we've been waiting for? It seems like for a long time and related, if you can, do you have any shipment statistics for all the boxboard grades within consumer?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't have the shipments statistics with the boxboard kind of grades at hand. And I think we're looking at through how our disclosure work I think it just opens we provide those in the future. As far as trends in the market, it's hard to talk about a t
componenttext: We don't have the shipments statistics with the boxboard kind of grades at hand. And I think we're looking at through how our disclosure work I think it just opens we provide those in the future. As far as trends in the market, it's hard to talk about a turnaround. But our volumes have been very strong in folding, as we said. And then on display, I think we have seen a noticeable pickup in promotional activity from many of our customers. I think that has been noticeable, and that has helped us drive the results that we talked about in this quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub from Buckingham Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions on the containerboard side. The first thing, I appreciate the details on the decisions you made on the footprint. There was a little bit of confusion. I realized that the reports were coming from the media and so again, any clarificati
componenttext: Couple of questions on the containerboard side. The first thing, I appreciate the details on the decisions you made on the footprint. There was a little bit of confusion. I realized that the reports were coming from the media and so again, any clarification from you is very helpful. But people are a little bit uncertain as to why the 2 mills they were, at least to the media is it was conveyed as indefinite closures and then fairly quickly that the mills were back on. And the outside view is that's fairly unusual and maybe that's just not understanding how you guys typically convey information, et cetera. But is there anything you can do to kind of clarify what was going on, on that that would be helpful.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'm going to let Jim Porter respond to that.
componenttext: Okay. So I'm going to let Jim Porter respond to that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, we have a large system with 16 mills now. And we operate that system very focused on providing our customers with good service, on-time delivery and superior products while balancing our supply with demand. And so we're constantly in a situa
componenttext: First of all, we have a large system with 16 mills now. And we operate that system very focused on providing our customers with good service, on-time delivery and superior products while balancing our supply with demand. And so we're constantly in a situation of designing the optimal portfolio production capacity to meet that demand. And with the addition of the SP Fiber acquisition, which we were delighted to close October 1, gave us the opportunity to really reassess our containerboard system and to make some important moves, utilizing those excellent assets at Dublin to better optimize our supply capability to our customers and improve our cost structure. So we were able to immediately take some capacity -- production capacity out with the indefinite idling of the Fernandina Beach paper machine 3 and the ville facilities followed quickly by the announcement of the permanent closure of the mill, which takes some time to properly close in order to provide an orderly shutdown and to optimally consume chemicals, raw materials, fiber, wood, et cetera. And we also then followed that same week with the indefinite idling of the Newburgh facility because of the weakness of the newsprint markets and to, again, balance our supply-demand scenario. So all of those decisions were executed to improve our capability to serve our customers and to improve our cost structure. We now are able to bring back the Fernandina Beach facility, which is an excellent paper machine-producing high-quality virgin containerboard for our domestic and international markets and ville recycled mill will also return. So that's -- we operated that balancing in a way that supported our customers well and improved our cost structure and as to the types of activities, you'll see us focusing on in the future.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. So am I right to interpret that -- so the initial move were on the indefinite closure of the 2 facilities, which then were restarted. It was a fluid situation and dependent on what was happening with some of the other facilities had an influe
componenttext: Okay. Great. So am I right to interpret that -- so the initial move were on the indefinite closure of the 2 facilities, which then were restarted. It was a fluid situation and dependent on what was happening with some of the other facilities had an influence on what the status of those initial moves were ultimately going to be?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Exactly. As I shared, we're always in a position of balancing supply-demand through a combination of maintenance and capital downtimes that you see we reported in this last quarter. We only had 3,000 tons of maintenance downtime. And the September quarter
componenttext: Exactly. As I shared, we're always in a position of balancing supply-demand through a combination of maintenance and capital downtimes that you see we reported in this last quarter. We only had 3,000 tons of maintenance downtime. And the September quarter, whereas in the prior quarter, it was 100 and -- a little over 100,000 tons maintenance downtime. And we've just shared that in the December quarter, we'll have 114,000 tons of maintenance downtime. So you can see within our system, the balancing of capacity with demand is one in which we use the levers of maintenance downtime flow back on certain paper machines and the indefinite idling of others and in some cases, permanent idling. But we have 16 mills that are operated in a way that we manage those paper machines production to demand.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Mark, the English language is just the English language, and people interpret the same words differently. I think just when we say indefinite, we just mean not definite and because we really don't want to create expectations. But we don't want to crea
componenttext: And Mark, the English language is just the English language, and people interpret the same words differently. I think just when we say indefinite, we just mean not definite and because we really don't want to create expectations. But we don't want to create unnecessary expectations, so when we said indefinite, I think we've had a meaning, which I think just was not -- was picked up differently than was the communication that we have. But I think Jim has covered the -- I think the logic. I think that's about all we can say in the matter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Ovshey with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Ovshey with Goldman Sachs.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. So just looking at the North American containerboard segment, you actually provided specific earnings numbers for that segment as part of corrugated. And as I look at the September quarter, it didn't show the improvement that we saw
componenttext: A couple of questions. So just looking at the North American containerboard segment, you actually provided specific earnings numbers for that segment as part of corrugated. And as I look at the September quarter, it didn't show the improvement that we saw in the first 3 quarters of the fiscal year. And I'm curious if there's anything else in the number that resulted in that. I know it had a really good year, so was there some incremental incentive compensation that was paid out at the mill converting level? Or anything else that maybe this quarter that didn't show up in the previous ones?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We did have some sequential increases from Q3 to Q4. And our fiber costs have been moderating. So on a year-over-year basis, we certainly were having dramatic benefits and reduced OCC. And they actually increased sequentially from Q3 to Q4. And we sold fe
componenttext: We did have some sequential increases from Q3 to Q4. And our fiber costs have been moderating. So on a year-over-year basis, we certainly were having dramatic benefits and reduced OCC. And they actually increased sequentially from Q3 to Q4. And we sold fewer tons.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And just on that question around the tons and also demand. So your box shipments were up 3, which is the majority of the tons. You said your exports were down to get the number in the 30s. But that would sort of imply a very material dropoff in ton
componenttext: Right. And just on that question around the tons and also demand. So your box shipments were up 3, which is the majority of the tons. You said your exports were down to get the number in the 30s. But that would sort of imply a very material dropoff in tons of domestic customers. Can you talk to that a little bit and what's happening there? And just as a follow on demand, you said October shipments were up 3 this year. Can you say what October was up last year being are you putting up 3% on top of really good growth from last year. And I'll stop here and turn over.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Jim talk about the domestic paperboard. just the box business has been performing very well on a volumetric basis for the past year and what October was up, I just don't have that number in my head. I think Jim can get if for you after the call.
componenttext: I'll let Jim talk about the domestic paperboard. just the box business has been performing very well on a volumetric basis for the past year and what October was up, I just don't have that number in my head. I think Jim can get if for you after the call. But we've had very consistent, I think, strong volume growth in box business for strong execution by that team in the marketplace.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the question was what was the mix of our business in the quarter? As I'm not quite sure exactly of the question. You mentioned export shipments being down, yes, in that quarter we're down 29,000 tons. And yet internally, with -- due to our stronge
componenttext: Yes. So the question was what was the mix of our business in the quarter? As I'm not quite sure exactly of the question. You mentioned export shipments being down, yes, in that quarter we're down 29,000 tons. And yet internally, with -- due to our stronger corrugated box shipments, we had greater containerboard flowing through our internal channels and yet a somewhat lower shipment to our domestic customer market and a slight increase in inventory. But the balance within our system is one in which we constantly look at our 3 channels: internal corrugated, external domestic, external international. And that's how we manage the system. So I'm not sure if that answered specifically your question.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Questions what are look like. He was looking for that reduction of our domestic shipments quarter-over-quarter. That's approximately 60,000 tons.
componenttext: Questions what are look like. He was looking for that reduction of our domestic shipments quarter-over-quarter. That's approximately 60,000 tons.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, just a couple for you. Just back to exports for a second. On last -- on the last call, you talked about things strong kraft linerboard markets around the world. And then you talked about export prices firming. And your exports, I believe, were up 11%
componenttext: Jim, just a couple for you. Just back to exports for a second. On last -- on the last call, you talked about things strong kraft linerboard markets around the world. And then you talked about export prices firming. And your exports, I believe, were up 11% year-over-year. Obviously, this call you've talked about exports being down from a year ago and prices being down both sequentially and from a year ago. So can you just help us understand what changed in the quarter with respect to export volumes and prices?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Global demand continues to be solid. We really see it across all of the global markets. Demand is there. But the impact of currency, however, has been pretty radical. And I certainly would not have forecasted the significant movement in the global currenc
componenttext: Global demand continues to be solid. We really see it across all of the global markets. Demand is there. But the impact of currency, however, has been pretty radical. And I certainly would not have forecasted the significant movement in the global currencies and the impact on price, which gives us the challenge of choosing where we -- which markets of the world that we operate in. And fortunately, we had a broad portfolio of customers, North America and across the globe, to be able to serve. And you've seen us making those decisions in this past quarter accordingly.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, Jim. And just not to beat a dead horse here, but in terms of what happened in October, have you previously taken either recycled mills or kraft linerboard machines down for just a couple of weeks, in this case? It just seemed from the outside to b
componenttext: Got it, Jim. And just not to beat a dead horse here, but in terms of what happened in October, have you previously taken either recycled mills or kraft linerboard machines down for just a couple of weeks, in this case? It just seemed from the outside to be a very short time to take those mills/machines down. But obviously, we don't know what's going on internally. Was it at all demand related? Or was it just -- is that typical for you to do take machines down for just a couple weeks in this case?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We've been operating for the past several years of matching supply with demand. And we've got a great containerboard system and a wonderful portfolio of customers. But we have more installed capacity than our customer base. And so we're always
componenttext: Absolutely. We've been operating for the past several years of matching supply with demand. And we've got a great containerboard system and a wonderful portfolio of customers. But we have more installed capacity than our customer base. And so we're always optimizing our production capacity to meet demand. And you have seen us indefinitely idle a number of our paper machines, both virgin and recycle. And we are always operating in a mode. In some cases, we're slowing assets back. So this frankly, was a very usual type of behavior, particularly in a quarter where we have very low maintenance and capital-related downtime.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, and just one last one. Can you talk about what the cost of market downtime is for the company and how you calculate that cost? And then separately, what the cost of the closure will be?
componenttext: Jim, and just one last one. Can you talk about what the cost of market downtime is for the company and how you calculate that cost? And then separately, what the cost of the closure will be?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just with respect to the cost of downtime, there's all sorts of different ways to look at it. Like if you look at the impact on our financial statements you want to model something, I think using something in the range of $120 to $150 per ton should do it
componenttext: Just with respect to the cost of downtime, there's all sorts of different ways to look at it. Like if you look at the impact on our financial statements you want to model something, I think using something in the range of $120 to $150 per ton should do it. I don't have the cash cost of the closure. I just don't have it in my head.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't the benefit is approximately $33 million cost and the capital avoidance impact, which on average, is approximately $4 million a year.
componenttext: I don't the benefit is approximately $33 million cost and the capital avoidance impact, which on average, is approximately $4 million a year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Just following up on the export shipments for the corrugated business. If I heard you correctly, it sounded as if you pulled back on exports, not because of demand, but more because of price realization in the export market. componenttext: The global markets are ones as in all markets in which there's a range of pricing in each of those markets of the world. And we make decisions to serve our customers and maximize our really is no specific market that we avoided. We just optimized our mix. We really don't share relative to those issues.

componenttextpreview: Okay. But the demand was there? You just chose to serve certain markets versus others, correct?
componenttext: Okay. But the demand was there? You just chose to serve certain markets versus others, correct?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, each of the economies of the world certainly have their own demand variation. But in total, the global demand for North American virgin containerboard virgin containerboard period is remains quite solid. And we constantly try to optimize our mix thr
componenttext: Well, each of the economies of the world certainly have their own demand variation. But in total, the global demand for North American virgin containerboard virgin containerboard period is remains quite solid. And we constantly try to optimize our mix through the 3 channels that we sell to.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I look at the $150 million of run rate synergy realization that you had in the quarter, I mean, it's exactly what you said you were going to do. You went out. You did it. But anything in there within the $150 million that sort of surprised you to
componenttext: Okay. If I look at the $150 million of run rate synergy realization that you had in the quarter, I mean, it's exactly what you said you were going to do. You went out. You did it. But anything in there within the $150 million that sort of surprised you to the upside? And anything to the downside as you work through the integration synergy realization process?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ward. I think we're pleased with our progress so far. If you look at the profile, as we talked about in the call last quarter, we entered the quarter with a $75 million run rate. We're clearly getting the benefits related to consolidation of some
componenttext: This is Ward. I think we're pleased with our progress so far. If you look at the profile, as we talked about in the call last quarter, we entered the quarter with a $75 million run rate. We're clearly getting the benefits related to consolidation of some of the corporate overhead pools. I would say that we have achieved about $50 million of the $100 million that we originally anticipated in the merger-related synergies. And then I think we're off to a very good start both in the procurement organization and then some of the internalization discussions that we had across both the mills in our packaging organization. So we were -- if I gave you a number, we were right around the $165 million is what we achieved in the quarter. I mean, that was the annualized exit rate that we achieved. And as we talked about, we're tracking it project-by-project. And now that we have P&Ls at the plant basis across the whole company, we're now building the linkages between the synergy projects and the plant P&Ls to make sure that we're actually realizing the benefits through the -- through our earnings.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari from Citi.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up on the corrugated business, and specifically Brazil. I was wondering how much exported in the quarter and maybe what percentage of production you can export from Brazil. And then does compete in the same export markets as your North Amer
componenttext: I had a follow-up on the corrugated business, and specifically Brazil. I was wondering how much exported in the quarter and maybe what percentage of production you can export from Brazil. And then does compete in the same export markets as your North American system? Or if you just talk about how those 2 systems meet each other in the global market.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We can assume within the Brazilian corrugated system approximately 80,000 tons a quarter. And we sell domestically and export approximately 40,000 tons a quarter. And the balance of Brazilian domestic sales and export is split pretty evenly. Now at the pr
componenttext: We can assume within the Brazilian corrugated system approximately 80,000 tons a quarter. And we sell domestically and export approximately 40,000 tons a quarter. And the balance of Brazilian domestic sales and export is split pretty evenly. Now at the present time, because of the currency-related impact of the Brazilian real, we are biasing towards international shipments to gain that favorable advantage. And much of that is in continent within South America. But there is some that goes into the European markets. And we do look at that in relation to the -- our broader international sales from our North American containerboard business. So...

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then in past quarters, you've given us updates on the installation of EVOLs in the U.S. And I was just wondering if you can give us an update there than just generally on the box plant optimization activities that's going on in k
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then in past quarters, you've given us updates on the installation of EVOLs in the U.S. And I was just wondering if you can give us an update there than just generally on the box plant optimization activities that's going on in kind of the legacy RockTenn containerboard system.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're in the process of installing EVOL number 16 and 17 out of 13. So we're implementing the program that we talked about. We just chose not to mention it just because we already had a lot of content in the call. The box plant system, the team is w
componenttext: Sure. We're in the process of installing EVOL number 16 and 17 out of 13. So we're implementing the program that we talked about. We just chose not to mention it just because we already had a lot of content in the call. The box plant system, the team is working, I think, exceptionally well and they're delivering great results. Bob, do you have anything to add?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not much to add to that. I just think it's a combination of both really terrific commercial execution in the box business in North America. As you mentioned in your prepared comments, the retention of customers has improved dramatically over the last year
componenttext: Not much to add to that. I just think it's a combination of both really terrific commercial execution in the box business in North America. As you mentioned in your prepared comments, the retention of customers has improved dramatically over the last year with just a focus on operating fundamentals around quality, service and reliability while we're building a more robust pipeline. So it's very gratifying that the business continues to outpace the industry as it has over the last year and just really rigorous focus on productivity and synergy at the operating level. And the EVOLs are a part of that story. But just a lot of blocking and tackling going on in that business that's leading to really great and improved results at the converting level.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Philip Ng from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Philip Ng from Jefferies.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The 114,000 tons of maintenance downtime you're taking in corrugated in the first quarter, how much of that is a pull-forward? And can give us a sense what the cadence is going be for the rest of the year? And also, assuming demand and pricing essentially
componenttext: The 114,000 tons of maintenance downtime you're taking in corrugated in the first quarter, how much of that is a pull-forward? And can give us a sense what the cadence is going be for the rest of the year? And also, assuming demand and pricing essentially holds, are you pretty much back to balance level? And you kind of frame what kind of a economic downtime you plan to take going forward?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first, we don't comment on economic downtime going forward. We've shared that in the October month. We took approximately 55,000 tons of economic downtime. However, I can't comment going forward. Relative to the 114,000 in the December quarter, I th
componenttext: Well, first, we don't comment on economic downtime going forward. We've shared that in the October month. We took approximately 55,000 tons of economic downtime. However, I can't comment going forward. Relative to the 114,000 in the December quarter, I think you used the word pull-up. I would not characterize there's been any pull-up that maintenance capital outage, downtime schedule is one which we build, frankly, years in advance to try to hit the cycles of recovery rebuilds and necessary inspections and maintenance regime. We need to execute our business. And that volume is, I think, would be usual. Relative to the go forward, we would have somewhat less volume than 114,000 in the next quarter, approximately the same in the third, and very little in our fourth quarter would be the normal cadence for our business. To your question on supply with demand, yes, we're matched with supply and demand, and it's something we plan for constantly. And the decisions we make, they are all focused on supplying our customers in the most efficient manner.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, a question for Ward. The buyback you guys did during the quarter, I think was a little north of $300 million. Is that kind of a good run rate going forward? I know you're below your leverage target? Or was it more being more opportunistic w
componenttext: Okay. I guess, a question for Ward. The buyback you guys did during the quarter, I think was a little north of $300 million. Is that kind of a good run rate going forward? I know you're below your leverage target? Or was it more being more opportunistic with the pullback in the market?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As you look at the leverage target the SP Fiber acquisition closed in the last week of the quarter rather than in the first week, we would've been at a pro forma leverage ratio of 2.2x, just on the -- just shy of the low end of our targeted range. I
componenttext: Sure. As you look at the leverage target the SP Fiber acquisition closed in the last week of the quarter rather than in the first week, we would've been at a pro forma leverage ratio of 2.2x, just on the -- just shy of the low end of our targeted range. I think Steve mentioned in his comments that we did -- we've got to make sure that we retain the continuity of interest that preserve the tax-free spend. So we had to actually track the common shareholders at a fund level. That did constrain us to a bit as we were in the quarter. But we did buyback over 5 million shares in the quarter. I think we've been consistent about executing against our leverage ratio. I don't think we're tied to the absolute target on any -- at any quarter. But I think we're -- our actions have been pretty consistent with the capital allocation strategy that we described at the announcement of the market.

componenttextpreview: The mix of business on that machine was pretty evenly split between bag and containerboard and it -- but it certainly does not fall great paper machines. Both of those machines really have excellent potential and capability and make a wonderful product. B
componenttext: The mix of business on that machine was pretty evenly split between bag and containerboard and it -- but it certainly does not fall great paper machines. Both of those machines really have excellent potential and capability and make a wonderful product. But it -- we just don't need those machines at the present time within our supply-demand balance scenario.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chercover from D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chercover from D.A. Davidson.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it's good to see that your North American containerboard margins are now north of 20%. However, they are still below that of some of your major competitors. And I'm wondering, can that gap to be closed with investment? Or is it something structural or
componenttext: So it's good to see that your North American containerboard margins are now north of 20%. However, they are still below that of some of your major competitors. And I'm wondering, can that gap to be closed with investment? Or is it something structural or pertaining to the furnished that you use?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We work hard on it every single day. And it's a combination of the types of things that we've been discussing relative to getting our portfolio of assets structured in the lowest cost manner. It's channel optimization of our customer portfolio across the
componenttext: We work hard on it every single day. And it's a combination of the types of things that we've been discussing relative to getting our portfolio of assets structured in the lowest cost manner. It's channel optimization of our customer portfolio across the world and it's business improvement and operating efficiency enhancement. Literally, thousands of things that our team is constantly working on. And we've got a nice portfolio on the table currently that we're looking forward to delivering on. And over time, I would see that gap closing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But it's fair to say that improvement in North American containerboards is not really something that we would put into the synergy bucket, correct?
componenttext: But it's fair to say that improvement in North American containerboards is not really something that we would put into the synergy bucket, correct?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Generally, not. I think there would be some areas where you'd have synergies -- we have better scale for providing corporate services. We have better scale for procurement. We're just on the direct -- we're not having North American containerboard assets
componenttext: Generally, not. I think there would be some areas where you'd have synergies -- we have better scale for providing corporate services. We have better scale for procurement. We're just on the direct -- we're not having North American containerboard assets as a result of the merger so you want expect improved. I'd just add on to Jim's comments, it's a competitive business. We can only improve our system. I think we have very good opportunities to improve our system. And that's was incorporated when we came up with our productivity target. And I feel very good about the team we have working on that on our ability to improve the results in the North American corrugated business. How that translates into a gap, I can't really respond to that.

componenttext: Yes. One of the things that we're trying to make sure that we preserve is the tax-free nature of the spin. So we actually had to go down to a fund level and identify those owners that were common share owners on July 1. And that's the opportunity set for the amount of shares that we've been able to repurchase.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015

componenttext: Yes. No I understand the importance of maintaining the tax structure. So you actually have to go to the fund level to say -- to see whose shares you're buying?

componenttextpreview: No, no. whose shares owned both MWV and -- at July -- on July 1. And one of the elements that we are doing -- we did file a POR, private ruling request, with the IRS about the spin of Specialty Chemicals. And this is one of the items that we are trying to
componenttext: No, no. whose shares owned both MWV and -- at July -- on July 1. And one of the elements that we are doing -- we did file a POR, private ruling request, with the IRS about the spin of Specialty Chemicals. And this is one of the items that we are trying to get a ruling from the IRS that will give us more freedom as we move forward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But presumably after March 1, you can just go kinds of ways, right?
componenttext: But presumably after March 1, you can just go kinds of ways, right?

componenttext: Yes. And we believe that we have, right now, we have a capacity of about 10 million shares that we can feel even before we get a ruling from the IRS that we have the ability to buy back.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to maybe come back to the SP Fiber stuff for a second. So I have a question around it and I do have a follow-up. But with SP stuff, could you maybe give us a sense? I think you paid a little over [ph] $300 million for it, but what exactly you bou
componenttext: I wanted to maybe come back to the SP Fiber stuff for a second. So I have a question around it and I do have a follow-up. But with SP stuff, could you maybe give us a sense? I think you paid a little over [ph] $300 million for it, but what exactly you bought? You have -- there were 2 locations. What did you have in mills? What capacity and such there? And then along those lines as well, what may have changed with dynamics between the time you announced things in August until we got to October that perhaps it sounds like, I think, my understanding is the majority of it or the bulk of the mills are closed.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, we're really delighted with the purchase of SP Fiber. And that we bought were 4 big, wide, fast low-cost paper machines and gives us lots of optionality in the production of containerboard grades as well as lightweight kraft bag, et cetera. And so
componenttext: Chris, we're really delighted with the purchase of SP Fiber. And that we bought were 4 big, wide, fast low-cost paper machines and gives us lots of optionality in the production of containerboard grades as well as lightweight kraft bag, et cetera. And so we're really quite pleased with having those assets, particularly Dublin. The Dublin mill, extremely well laid out, very efficient, a lot of upside potential for further improvement in their cost structure by operating as a part of our larger containerboard systems. So we just see exceptional opportunity. The Newburgh mill all along with the newsprint production at that mill was one in which we were we knew would be challenging. And the newsprint market, I think you all understand as well as we do, is on a continuing decline. So what we have in newsprint in Newburgh is the optionality on in these 2 excellent big wide, fast paper machines that give us the opportunity to consider what future needs may be for those assets. But currently, we're indefinitely idling them, and that improves the cash flow of the acquisition and the earnings in that case.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe some clarification and what was the capacity on each of those, the newsprint machine and then the stuff in Dublin?
componenttext: Maybe some clarification and what was the capacity on each of those, the newsprint machine and then the stuff in Dublin?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It depends on what grades you run them on. But round numbers, you could make up to 300,000 tons a piece on each of those machines, depending upon what products they're producing.
componenttext: It depends on what grades you run them on. But round numbers, you could make up to 300,000 tons a piece on each of those machines, depending upon what products they're producing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
