componenttextpreview: Sure. As you look at the leverage target, had the SP Fiber acquisition closed in the last week of the quarter rather than in the first week, we would've been at a pro forma leverage ratio of 2.2x, just on the -- just shy of the low end of our targeted ran
componenttext: Sure. As you look at the leverage target, had the SP Fiber acquisition closed in the last week of the quarter rather than in the first week, we would've been at a pro forma leverage ratio of 2.2x, just on the -- just shy of the low end of our targeted range. I think Steve mentioned in his comments that we did -- we've got to make sure that we retain the continuity of interest to preserve the tax-free spin. So we've had to actually track the common shareholders at a fund level. That did constrain us to a bit as we weren't [ph] in the quarter. But we did buy back over 5 million shares in the quarter. I think we've been consistent about executing against our leverage ratio. I don't think we're tied to the absolute target on any -- at any quarter. But I think we're -- our actions have been pretty consistent with the capital allocation strategy that we described at the announcement of the merger.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve and Ward, first question -- and Jim, first question -- and Bob, actually, is on the depreciation and amortization. Does that include -- the $285 million run rate, does that include chemicals or is that taken out?
componenttext: Yes, Steve and Ward, first question -- and Jim, first question -- and Bob, actually, is on the depreciation and amortization. Does that include -- the $285 million run rate, does that include chemicals or is that taken out?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That does include chemicals.
componenttext: That does include chemicals.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that'll stay there until the spin actually occurs?
componenttext: Okay. So that'll stay there until the spin actually occurs?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, you mentioned the cost that Coshocton was running. That sort of implies that either you are losing money there, or -- is that a fair statement? Or at least, you weren't really getting much contribution, I guess, in recent months from that
componenttext: Okay. And then, you mentioned the cost that Coshocton was running. That sort of implies that either you are losing money there, or -- is that a fair statement? Or at least, you weren't really getting much contribution, I guess, in recent months from that mill?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- I don't think that's -- we can go over that with you, but it's -- it was doing fine.
componenttext: I think -- I don't think that's -- we can go over that with you, but it's -- it was doing fine.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. Okay. And then, looking at Newberg, I know that the one machine there that was converted to packaging papers, I guess, loosely defined, was not that long ago, I think, in March. And I understood the machine had about 200,000 tons of capacit
componenttext: Okay, got you. Okay. And then, looking at Newberg, I know that the one machine there that was converted to packaging papers, I guess, loosely defined, was not that long ago, I think, in March. And I understood the machine had about 200,000 tons of capacity. And could you sort of give us an idea of how much of that machine was running medium versus bag, paper and other things?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The mix of business on that machine was pretty evenly split between bag and containerboard and it -- but it certainly was not full. Great paper machines. Both of those machines really have excellent potential and capability and make a wonderful product. B
componenttext: The mix of business on that machine was pretty evenly split between bag and containerboard and it -- but it certainly was not full. Great paper machines. Both of those machines really have excellent potential and capability and make a wonderful product. But it -- we just don't need those machines at the present time within our supply-demand balance scenario.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chercover from D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Chercover from D.A. Davidson.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it's good to see that your North American containerboard margins are now north of 20%. However, they are still below that of some of your major competitors. And I'm wondering, can that gap be closed with investment? Or is it something structural or per
componenttext: So it's good to see that your North American containerboard margins are now north of 20%. However, they are still below that of some of your major competitors. And I'm wondering, can that gap be closed with investment? Or is it something structural or pertaining to the furnish that you use?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We work hard on it every single day, and it's a combination of the types of things that we've been discussing relative to getting our portfolio of assets structured in the lowest-cost manner. It's channel optimization of our customer portfolio across the
componenttext: We work hard on it every single day, and it's a combination of the types of things that we've been discussing relative to getting our portfolio of assets structured in the lowest-cost manner. It's channel optimization of our customer portfolio across the world and it's business improvement and operating efficiency enhancement, literally thousands of things that our team is constantly working on. And we've got a nice portfolio on the table currently that we're looking forward to delivering on. And over time, I would see that gap closing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But it's fair to say that improvement in North American containerboard is not really something that we would put into the synergy bucket, correct?
componenttext: But it's fair to say that improvement in North American containerboard is not really something that we would put into the synergy bucket, correct?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Generally not. I think there would be some areas where you'd have synergies. We have better scale for providing corporate services. We have better scale for procurement. But just on the direct, we're not adding North American containerboard assets as a re
componenttext: Generally not. I think there would be some areas where you'd have synergies. We have better scale for providing corporate services. We have better scale for procurement. But just on the direct, we're not adding North American containerboard assets as a result of the merger so you wouldn't expect it to improve. And I'd just add on to Jim's comments of -- it's a competitive business. We can only improve our system. I think we have very good opportunities to improve our system, and that's what was incorporated when we came up with our productivity target. And I feel very good about the team we have working on that and our ability to improve the results in the North American corrugated business. How that translates into a gap, I can't really respond to that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And sorry if I'm somehow missing this, but can you clarify how open-market purchases of your equity have any implications for the ratio of RockTenn and MeadWestvaco ownership?
componenttext: Okay. And sorry if I'm somehow missing this, but can you clarify how open-market purchases of your equity have any implications for the ratio of RockTenn and MeadWestvaco ownership?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- one of the things that we're trying to make sure that we preserve is the tax-free nature of the spin. And there's the continuity of ownership that we maintain the 50.1% through the period of the spin. So we actually had to go down to a fund le
componenttext: Yes. The -- one of the things that we're trying to make sure that we preserve is the tax-free nature of the spin. And there's the continuity of ownership that we maintain the 50.1% through the period of the spin. So we actually had to go down to a fund level and identify those owners that were common share owners on July 1. And that's the opportunity set for the amount of shares that we've been able to repurchase.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I understand the importance of maintaining the tax structure. So you actually have to go to the fund level to say -- to see whose shares you're buying.
componenttext: Yes. No, I understand the importance of maintaining the tax structure. So you actually have to go to the fund level to say -- to see whose shares you're buying.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no. Whose shares owned both MWV and -- at July -- on July 1. And one of the elements that we are doing -- we did file a PLR, private letter ruling request, with the IRS about the spin of Specialty Chemicals, and this is one of the items that we are tr
componenttext: No, no. Whose shares owned both MWV and -- at July -- on July 1. And one of the elements that we are doing -- we did file a PLR, private letter ruling request, with the IRS about the spin of Specialty Chemicals, and this is one of the items that we are trying to get a ruling from the IRS that will give us more freedom as we move forward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: But presumably, after March 1, you can just go guns a-blazing, right?
componenttext: But presumably, after March 1, you can just go guns a-blazing, right?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we believe that we have -- right now, we have a capacity of about 10 million shares that we can feel -- even before we get a ruling from the IRS, that we have the ability to buy back.
componenttext: Yes, and we believe that we have -- right now, we have a capacity of about 10 million shares that we can feel -- even before we get a ruling from the IRS, that we have the ability to buy back.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to maybe come back to the SP Fiber stuff for a second. So I have a question around it, and I do have a follow-up. But with the SP stuff, could you maybe give us a sense -- I think you paid a little under $300 million for it, but what exactly you
componenttext: I wanted to maybe come back to the SP Fiber stuff for a second. So I have a question around it, and I do have a follow-up. But with the SP stuff, could you maybe give us a sense -- I think you paid a little under $300 million for it, but what exactly you bought? You have -- there were 2 locations. What did you have in mills? What was capacity and such there? And then, along those lines as well, what may have changed with dynamics between the time you announced things in August until we got to October that, perhaps, it sounds like, I think -- my understanding is the majority of it or the bulk of the mills are closed.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, we're really delighted with the purchase of SP Fiber, and what we bought were 4 big, wide, fast low-cost paper machines and gives us lots of optionality in the production of containerboard grades as well as lightweight kraft bag, et cetera. And so
componenttext: Chris, we're really delighted with the purchase of SP Fiber, and what we bought were 4 big, wide, fast low-cost paper machines and gives us lots of optionality in the production of containerboard grades as well as lightweight kraft bag, et cetera. And so we're really quite pleased with having those assets, particularly Dublin. The Dublin mill, extremely well laid out, very efficient, a lot of upside potential for further improvement in their cost structure by operating at a part -- as a part of our larger containerboard systems. So we just see exceptional opportunity. The Newberg mill, all along with the newsprint production at that mill, was one in which we were -- we knew would be challenging. And the newsprint market, I think, you all understand as well as we do, is on a continuing decline. So what we have in newsprint -- in Newberg is the optionality on these 2 excellent, big, wide, fast paper machines that give us the opportunity to consider what future needs may be for those assets. But currently, we're indefinitely idling them, and that improves the cash flow of the acquisition and the earnings from that case.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe some clarification there. What was the capacity on each of those, the newsprint machines, and then the stuff in Dublin?
componenttext: Maybe some clarification there. What was the capacity on each of those, the newsprint machines, and then the stuff in Dublin?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It depends on what grades you run them on, but round numbers, you could make up to 300,000 tons apiece on each of those machines, depending upon what products they're producing.
componenttext: It depends on what grades you run them on, but round numbers, you could make up to 300,000 tons apiece on each of those machines, depending upon what products they're producing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then my second question was, during the quarter, we had a transaction in the chemical space with Arizona. That probably gives us a reasonable look at, as packaging analysts and primarily chemicals analysts, or a reasonable read a
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then my second question was, during the quarter, we had a transaction in the chemical space with Arizona. That probably gives us a reasonable look at, as packaging analysts and primarily chemicals analysts, or a reasonable read as to what a multiple might look like for Ingevity. Why or why not might that be a reasonable thing to think about or not?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob, do you want to...
componenttext: Bob, do you want to...

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Chris, this is Bob Beckler. Yes, I think you're right in that it's a data point. But you really have to look at Ingevity in the broader specialty chemical space. And there's just been widespread valuations in that space that are generally still ve
componenttext: Yes. So Chris, this is Bob Beckler. Yes, I think you're right in that it's a data point. But you really have to look at Ingevity in the broader specialty chemical space. And there's just been widespread valuations in that space that are generally still very, very attractive. While we do compete in the space that the Arizona Chemical participates in on pine chemicals, I would say, we fly at a higher level in terms of targeting premium applications for pine chemicals and derivatives. For example, the pavement technologies or asphalt emulsifiers that we have in that business, which Arizona largely does not have, are very attractive and performed extremely well, record sales in the last quarter. So it is a data point, but I would say, there's also a lot of apples and oranges. So I wouldn't take it too literally.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones from Deutsche Bank.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about the home, health & beauty business. They haven't been getting a lot of attention on these calls. But you talked, I think, last quarter about some investment to meet customer needs. Can you just kind of elaborate on whether that is t
componenttext: I wanted to talk about the home, health & beauty business. They haven't been getting a lot of attention on these calls. But you talked, I think, last quarter about some investment to meet customer needs. Can you just kind of elaborate on whether that is to kind of grow volumes, what you're kind of expecting in that business? And then, also how core is this business to you?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob?
componenttext: Bob?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Debbie, it's Bob Beckler, again, and thanks for giving a little attention to what is really a great business in the packaging portfolio. Steve mentioned in his prepared comments, it had a terrific quarter, and they continue to build on this track record o
componenttext: Debbie, it's Bob Beckler, again, and thanks for giving a little attention to what is really a great business in the packaging portfolio. Steve mentioned in his prepared comments, it had a terrific quarter, and they continue to build on this track record of improvement that you have seen in the business over the last 2 years now, which has come from a combination of things. It's been a better commercial strategy targeting more attractive niches in the global market, better plant loadings and better productivity. And we have made incremental investments in that business that are required to support our customers, our partners with their particular rollouts. So it's all working together and continues to show a very positive trend. In terms of the fit question, we like it for 3 reasons. One is the overlap that the home, health & beauty dispensing system business has with our other paper and packaging businesses. Roughly $1 million -- $1 billion of WestRock sales are to customers that buy dispenser products and other paperboard and packaging products from WestRock. We also have really strong relationships with these customers through the dispensing system business, because it's a highly technical and innovative business, and so these are more like partnerships, which, then, we can leverage with our other packaging businesses. And then finally, it's a global business, which gives us the opportunity to reach beyond the North American borders. So we still feel very good about the fit and the performance of that business.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Second, one final question. You mentioned earlier you don't make the public announcements on your idle mills, and I appreciate these are difficult decisions, but can you help us understand going forward, does it make sense for you, when yo
componenttext: That's helpful. Second, one final question. You mentioned earlier you don't make the public announcements on your idle mills, and I appreciate these are difficult decisions, but can you help us understand going forward, does it make sense for you, when you're managing supply with demand, to idle mills for a short duration? Or is this primarily just kind of related to the inclusion of Dublin in your system?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- I think, as we shared, Debbie, that the levers that we have to balance supply with demand -- and demand varies, right? It depends upon our North American Corrugated Packaging business, global demand, et cetera. So we have to be flexible in the larg
componenttext: The -- I think, as we shared, Debbie, that the levers that we have to balance supply with demand -- and demand varies, right? It depends upon our North American Corrugated Packaging business, global demand, et cetera. So we have to be flexible in the large system we operate between maintenance and capital downtime, idling and slowback. So you will see us operating that flexibility in a way that we think is the optimal way to supply our customers at the lowest cost. So short answer, we will -- you will see us continuing to use those levers going forward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montréal.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Mark Wilde from Bank of Montréal.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I wondered if we could just kind of take a step back for a minute. For those of us who have been covering the company for a long time, we were recall that Smurfit-Stone was a pretty choppy ride for the first 12 months of that deal. Anything you're
componenttext: Steve, I wondered if we could just kind of take a step back for a minute. For those of us who have been covering the company for a long time, we were recall that Smurfit-Stone was a pretty choppy ride for the first 12 months of that deal. Anything you're trying to do differently this time?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. I think, yes, we are, but they're very different situations. So Smurfit was literally an acquisition. This is a merger. And it's great that it's a merger, because one of the big issues we had in Smurfit, I'm going to put into the
componenttext: That's a great question. I think, yes, we are, but they're very different situations. So Smurfit was literally an acquisition. This is a merger. And it's great that it's a merger, because one of the big issues we had in Smurfit, I'm going to put into the category of culture, that we were integrating into our organization. At the time, I was CFO. My job tripled overnight, and then, the Smurfit organization had not just been successful over a long period of time. And that is -- continues to be a lesson for me of how that can really impact a culture. This merger is very much different. Because I think most of the people on the call would have known of both companies, and WestRock's bringing the best of both companies to the table. We're highly complementary. I think you could pro forma either company, and I guess, we are trying to pro forma both companies going forward. And we've got a tremendous future together, which is better than either company would have on its own. So depending on what side you're on, we can go through -- enumerate the opportunities. But we effectively -- from a culture standpoint, we've put a much greater emphasis on that. And so we are moving beyond -- this is a merger of 2 companies, but it's a creation of a new company, which is WestRock, and we're working together. I'm very optimistic about the future of the company. And I think on -- in the call, I think we focused a lot on a very discrete set of actions we took, which, I think, were misinterpreted by the business. But underlying that, I think we're performing at an exceptional level, that we're delivering the merger and performance improvements. Somebody asked about is there -- was there a surprise? And I would like to think that there's an expectation we're going to go out and get that. But we are meeting that expectation, I'd say, with enthusiasm across the organization. And that's going to end up -- what we need to do that to be successful. While all that is going on, we have -- I think each one of our businesses on a day-to-day basis is operating exceptionally well. I'm very excited about the reaction we're getting from the customers. They're coming to us and asking us what can -- what's this about, and we're having a conversation, which is a little bit early to tell what the ultimate tale of the tape is, but I think it's going to position us to be a remarkably successful company going forward. So thank you for the opportunity, Mark. [indiscernible]

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, that's helpful. I have, just as a follow-on, a couple of questions around pricing and volume. You had flagged $17 million of pricing weakness in Consumer Packaging. And then, over in pine chemicals, you had talked about both pricing and volume
componenttext: All right, that's helpful. I have, just as a follow-on, a couple of questions around pricing and volume. You had flagged $17 million of pricing weakness in Consumer Packaging. And then, over in pine chemicals, you had talked about both pricing and volume pressure from petrochemical-based alternatives, and I wondered if you could just provide a little color on both of those.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Bob. Let me start with Specialty Chemicals, and then we can come back to Consumer Packaging. I think, as you know, having all of the business, the Specialty Chemical business that will become Ingevity, is a highly flexible business around its r
componenttext: Mark, it's Bob. Let me start with Specialty Chemicals, and then we can come back to Consumer Packaging. I think, as you know, having all of the business, the Specialty Chemical business that will become Ingevity, is a highly flexible business around its refinery system. And oilfield technologies has definitely seen the impact of what's happening in the broader sector. But let me give you a couple of statistics to put it into perspective. So well counts -- oil well counts are down about 65% across the industry year-on-year, yet our revenue in that specific sector is only down about 40%. So we're actually taking share in the downmarket in oilfield, which is a market that we really like for its profitability. And that's because we just have really great, highly differentiated products. And at the same time, we're able to shift business over to the industrial specialties. Yes, there's been some pricing movement with the dislocations that are occurring, very modest offset in volume. But as I said earlier in one of my answers, we're able to move into some other areas that help offset that volume decline. And asphalt pavement technologies has been an example of that, up 19% versus prior year. So a lot of big movements in the business, but really great effort by the team in managing through what's been a fairly volatile period of time. And I think it'll position them well for the future. Mark, can you repeat your question on consumer?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just you had flagged $17 million of pricing weakness in Consumer Packaging. So I'm just trying understand where that is. We have -- we've all heard some reports about sort of weakness in international SBS markets. I'm just trying to understand whethe
componenttext: Yes. Just you had flagged $17 million of pricing weakness in Consumer Packaging. So I'm just trying understand where that is. We have -- we've all heard some reports about sort of weakness in international SBS markets. I'm just trying to understand whether that's the whole story there or whether you're seeing it in some other markets.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. Well, I think it's both the paperboard and converting. In answer to your question, we have definitely seen the FX impact to the downside on both revenue and translation back into profitability with paperboard exports, less so on the converting
componenttext: Yes, Mark. Well, I think it's both the paperboard and converting. In answer to your question, we have definitely seen the FX impact to the downside on both revenue and translation back into profitability with paperboard exports, less so on the converting side, with the exception of our beverage business, which -- our beverage multipack business is about 50% outside of North America. And so there has been some FX exposure there as well. On the converting side, overall, if you step back, we were really pleased with how we're performing in our markets. Our volumes are up. We're managing well in terms of mix and pipeline development with customers. And so overall, I think the converting side of consumer solutions is performing well. Anything, Jim, you would add on the paperboard side?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think we like the positions we're in with respect to our specialty products that supply the high-end niches of the paperboard markets, North America and globally. We do feel some pressure from FX, which we're all aware of. But fund
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think we like the positions we're in with respect to our specialty products that supply the high-end niches of the paperboard markets, North America and globally. We do feel some pressure from FX, which we're all aware of. But fundamentally, the business is operating extremely well, and we have a product portfolio that's in demand, and we like our position.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've got an excellent system. So I just -- if I can kind of read through this, it sounds like that $17 million is mostly on the mill side, and it probably skews to kind of the international trade component of the business. Is that correct?
componenttext: You've got an excellent system. So I just -- if I can kind of read through this, it sounds like that $17 million is mostly on the mill side, and it probably skews to kind of the international trade component of the business. Is that correct?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a good assumption. I think it's somewhat balanced between our -- it's largely international sales across the portfolio of specialty products.
componenttext: It's a good assumption. I think it's somewhat balanced between our -- it's largely international sales across the portfolio of specialty products.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Mark, I'm not -- we need to provide a better answer. We will do that in the Q that we'll file. I just -- I think, rather than try to go through it, I think that business has so many elements to it. To try to isolate that specific price risk is a little
componenttext:
So Mark, I'm not -- we need to provide a better answer. We will do that in the Q that we'll file. I just -- I think, rather than try to go through it, I think that business has so many elements to it. To try to isolate that specific price risk is a little bit difficult for us right now. So we'll just include it in our Q next quarter [ph], so everybody will see that, okay? 
Operator, I think we're complete with the call. Again, I would like to express my appreciation for everybody taking the time to listen to the call, and we will speak to you next quarter. Thanks.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, speakers, and that concludes today's conference. Thank you all for participating. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you, speakers, and that concludes today's conference. Thank you all for participating. You may now disconnect.
